Starbucks is good but it's a treat to get your coffee from the Kona Mountain Coffee shop which is underneath the Grand Waikikian....we liked it better but it did not open till 9 AM.Definitely ask for use of the hospitality lounge if your flight leaves later than checkout. We did not take showers but did spend a few minutes in there. It was a nice benefit.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: We had a nice stay at the HHV Tapa Tower over 5 years ago and this time, we decided to try the newest property, Grand Waikikian. We were not disappointed. Having spent 9 nights there, our family will return to the GW on our next visit to Honolulu. Here's why: in addition to the location (HHV is perfect - convenient without the hustle-bustle of busier areas), the layout (convenience of having suite with a full kitchen and washer/dryer set cannot be beat!), we really appreciated the Concierge Desk. The staff were very friendly and helpful with our many questions. They gave good information and advice from restaurant recommendations to water activities to excursions. They made dinner reservations, arranged surfing lessons and booked our visits to popular sites (e.g. Pearl Harbor; Wakilea Premium Outlet; Hanauma Bay), all with smiles and good wishes to us for a great time.We were glad to be upgraded from partial oceanview to having a fantastic oceanview (but still under the same rate category as "partial" oceanview). When we reported a minor issue with the in-suite dryer, our trouble call was answered quickly (approx 15 mins). The HHV staff member was friendly and efficiently repaired the issue. While we had easy access to the beach we could use the pools (also the one in Lagoon Tower) when we wanted a change. The free DVD rental with very good selection of movies was great for our downtime. Our teenagers loved having our own in-suite PS3 system. Like others have mentioned in this forum, the only less-than-perfect item is their open bathroom in the master bdrm (we stayed in a 2-bdrm suite). This concept works for couples only and even so, it would have been nicer to have privacy in the bath. This observation does not change our favourable impression of the GW though and as a family we agreed to stay here again when we next return to Honolulu.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: This is my family's second trip to Hilton Hawaiian Village. We stayed at Lagoon tower's 1 bedroom unit in 2010 and decided to try Grand Waikikian's 1 bedroom unit this time, in slow season (so we can afford the exchange points). We were very impressed with the unit. Definitely a plus to have washer and dryer in the room as we were travelling with children. We were first given room 1712 which faces Ala Moana Boulevard. We were not impressed with the noise from the lanai. We asked for a room change and were moved to unit 901 the following day (due to all the units being full on the day we arrived). What a difference! 901 is one of two units facing directly south (partial ocean view past Lagoon Tower and Marina). 901 is also a corner unit with windows facing east. We were enchanted by the luau on the parking rooftop Sundays to Thursdays. We were so close, we could hear and see everything. Be sure to ask ahead of time for a partial ocean view if you are doing points exchange. 9th floor is also only partly taken up by units -- we think the remaining are for utilities, equipment, etc. The hallways are very quiet, and we had free Honolulu Advertiser paper by the elevator each day. The unit had a very spacious master bedroom. Kitchen was nicely finished, with a open concept. We had a separate eating area and living room. The bathroom had very nice glass door shower and large soaker tub.We had stellar service as well. We had a low battery indicator on the room safe. When we called, the security personnel came within 1 minute to open the safe for us. Then the service person came within the hour to replace the battery. We also had quick service with requests for toilet paper, and problems with Sony Playstation. We were given unlimited access to DVDs (machines near elevators). We weren't sure if the Blu Ray DVDs were scratched or the Sony Playstation, but 2 out of 3 DVDs had issue playing. We told the service person and he replaced the Playstation within an hour.The 8th floor Arrival/Departure lounge for owners was very impressive. (We could have used it when we last stayed at Lagoon tower, but did not need to due to our flight times.) There's a separate room for children to play (bring your own toys and DVDs as activities are limited). There are free lockers and showers -- very clean and luxurious. They also had several areas laid out for different groups to sit and relax with some privacy. We didn't realize that we could have used this lounge everyday. There were juices, teas, coffee for refreshments. There are 2 laptops and printer for limited use (15 minutes max, print 5 pages max). We used this to print our boarding passes. The staff were very friendly.As for pools, we were familiar with all of them from our last visit (see my previous review in 2010). I was surprised that the paradise pool was so busy on the weekends, as this was supposed to be slow season, but we were always able to find chairs. The lagoon and beaches are just as we remembered. Lots of room to accommodate everyone.We enjoyed watching the Friday night 7:45pm fireworks from the beach. We almost felt we were too close, feeling the heat and the thunder. It was spectacular.In comparing the Grand Waikikian and Lagoon Tower 1 bedroom suites, I would say that location wise, Lagoon Tower is closer to the rest of the Hilton Hawaiian Village shops and restaurants, and pools. Grand Waikikian is much more luxurious. We are already planning to come back Spring Break 2013, but due to the points we have, we will be going to Lagoon tower. We will put up with shared laundry facilities to be in paradise for 1 week :)

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: This was our fifth trip to Hawaii and our second trip back to Oahu. It was our first stay however at GWS. Spent eight days. Couldn't have ask for a better stay. The property and staff were great. We were on the 19 floor in a corner Ocean Front Two Bedroom Suite along with two other family members. Loved it. Plenty of room to come and go as we wanted without disturbing each other. Only thing I will say is I wish the parking was a bit less expensive ($24 per day). I ended up parking at the Hale Koa next door (Cash Only). Very affordable, a bit of a walk, but after all you're in Hawaii and walking is part of the gig. Would highly recommend this property to all.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: The Grand Waikikian made me rethink my needs when vacationing with my family. My stay was excellent!!!!! If you have kids like mine they eat and munch the whole day. I was able to buy enough food at Costco to last us 7 days! Having a kitchen with a regular size fridge is wonderful. I can store EVERYTHING! I saved alot by cooking 80% of our trip. Now the washer and dryer is also another requirement when vacationing. I don't need to bring a lot of clothes. Another plus is the free DVD red box style rental in the lobby. Gave us something to do during downtime in the room. They also have the best pool in Waikiki in my opinion, plus the lagoon is great for water activities. I won't think twice when booking our next Oahu trip. I'll definitely go back to the Grand Waikikian.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: We stayed in the Grand Waikikian tower in a 1 bedroom suite for a family of 4. It was spacious and very nicely appointed. We stayed for 6 nights at the end of March/beginning of April 2012, and the 1 BR was spacious enough that we didn't feel as if we were stepping on each other - we could spread out a bit. The kitchen was functional enough that we cooked nearly every meal in our suite. I highly recommend hitting one of the local farmer's markets for amazing produce. Our 1BR was "city view" which meant facing Ala Moana, a very busy road. In addition, they were doing road construction at night. However, the sliding door and windows installed in the unit was amazing and blocked out 100% of the noise. The Grand Waikikian rooms have a washer/dryer right in the unit, which was great. The proximity to the lagoon and the beach is what really made it fantastic.We have two 6 year old kiddos who are good swimmers, but inexperienced in oceans. The beach is excellent - very protected so we didn't have to worry about the kids getting swept out in a big wave. Beaches farther east on Waikiki had a LOT more wave action and I was glad we weren't trying to swim there. But the lagoon was the bigger hit with our kids. They liked that the water was warmer, and had a blast with a stand up paddle board we rented a couple times.We liked it so much that we will be back again in a few years!

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: We stayed at Grand Waikikian Suites for a few days in March 2012. Honestly we are disappointed. Let me write cons and pros below:Cons:(1) When we checked in, we were told that they only have a room with full beds. When I told her that I reserved a room with a King size bed, she just told me "That was your request. We didn't have a room." She even did not tell us sorry! I definitely did not like the stuck-up attitude of this black long-haired Japanese-looking lady at the reception.(2) Moreover, right after we checked in, we were taken to "Concierge," who explained us the amenities of the vast complex. But there was a true reason why the Concierge had to explain this to us, instead of the stuck-up lady at the reception. They want to sell their condos to customers! This hotel is basically a condo/time share, and rents rooms when they cannot fill the room with time share. Therefore, whenever a hotel guest shows up, they want to sell their condo to us! The Concierge lady even asked my annual salary (to see whether I qualify for their credit I suppose)! I wasted like 30 minutes for this crap before we finally checked into our room!(3) It is a part of the huge Hilton Hawaiian Village (sharing with other Hilton hotels). This implies that, even though you might be paying much more than a typical Hilton hotel in Waikiki, all the pools and stores are shared with guests from other Hiltons. Basically, a lot of family and kids. It was impossible to find a chair on the pool side. You probably paid like 400+ per night, but you end up sharing everything except for the room with people paying like 150-200.(4) Parking is not connected to the hotel, and you need to walk a long walk. If you choose to use valet, you wait 15 min to get your car instead of walking for 10 min.(5) Staff are not used for hotel guests. When I asked what time the beds are made, I was told "we clean up the room every once a week. You need to pay for more." The truth is, for a hotel guest, they do bed making every day, but many staff don't remember that, it seems.(6) The bed (two full size instead of one king) is one of the worst that i have ever had in a decent hotel. My hip sank like 5 inches. Unless you sleep n the edge of the bed, you suffer this sinking... Both my girlfriend and i suffered a back pain. It is unacceptable for a decently priced hotel.(7) I wish they had salt, pepper, and some basic stuff in the kitchen. You need to buy everything!(8) They have a lot of restaurants and bars, but all are sort of disappointing. They are what you should expect from 200-per-night hotel for large tourist groups.Pros:(1) It's a condo. You have a full kitchen. If you don't want to waste money for not-so-great food in Waikiki (compared with Tokyo or NY), you can cook yourself!(2) The room is huge, equipped with DVD players (there is a free DVD rental service for guests), PS3, and iPhone-compatible stereo. If you like the feel of living, you'll be happy.(3) There are a lot of pools and an artificial lagoon, although the temperature of all are definitely below the ocean (it was cold!)(4) It's conveniently located, in the middle between Ala Moana Shopping center, and Galleria DFS. Both are sort of walking distance (we drove).At the end, if you want a kitchen, but don't care about a lot of crowded pools or not being on the beach, Trump is a much much better option for possibly similar prices. If you don't care about kitchen, well, there is no reason to choose this hotel. Choose some suite room in one of the smaller but better-graded hotels. I recommend Halekulani but it's a bit pricy. But there are other options, too, in Waikiki.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: I loved staying at the the Grand Waikikian because their rooms were very large and comfortable. Out of the five pools you can go to in the the Waikiki little village that was also the only pool that was heated and had three slides. Also about 100 feet away is a lagoon and beyond that a little farther is the ocean! I stayed at about three hotel while in Hawaii and the Grand Wakikian was by far the best.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: As owners, we have visited a number of the Grand Vacation properties and particularly enjoyed our week at Kings Land in Waikaloa prior to a week in Waikiki. Despite more than 20 Hawaiian trips, been a long time since we visited Waikiki / Oahu and were apprehensive. No more. Grand Waikikian is new, the entire Hilton complex is first class and all the "little" items that make the difference are present at the Grand Waikikian. Upscale rooms, appliances, HD TV (but ask how to use the remote / channels---why they don't have instructions is beyond me. the maintenance man who came had 8 calls backed up just to show folks how to operate the remote....once you learned great channel choices etc. but a very solvable problem that should be addressed)...we had a wonderful view from the 26th floor. Elevators are quick and waits short to non-existent. NIcely stocked convenience store next to the elevators and lots of shopping very close. Happy Hour at Tropics is a must do. Best property / accommodations I saw.....and the Hilton Hotel--while VERY NICE is a zoo with 3300 rooms....too many moving parts for our taste but probably great for families. Can't go wrong with any of the HIlton set-ups at Waikiki

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: We stayed at the Grand Waikikian for our 21st anniversary, a trip we have planned for many years. The grounds and public areas were very beautiful and interseting. The room we had was a one bedroom with a sleeper sofa in the living room, a full kitchen and dining area. Full size washer and dryer(we had issues with our dryer, but it was resolved later that week). We bought some groceries from the ABC store down the block and would have breakfast in our suite, before setting out to explore the island. The amenities were perfect and the pool, lagoon and beach were nice and isolated from the the main row of Waikiki beach hotels. Dining on site was very expensive and the quality was less than we expected(live and learn), but the restaurants near by had great food and were not too far if a walk. Overall, we really liked our stay and would live to stay there again, hopefully sooner than later.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: Checkin went without a hitch and we were in our room an hour before official checkin time. We were in a nicely appointed, one bedroom suite with what they called a city view, but we could see a small patch of the ocean if we leaned out on our balcony a bit. As usual with HGVC properties, there was a dearth of towel bars in the bathroom but being used to this shortcoming we brought some stick-on Command hooks to keep towels off the floor. Front desk warned us that the DVD rental machines were troublesome and they were right. We had to get replacement cards three times and sometimes the machine would not vend the disk we had rented. Having stayed at the Hawaiian Village before, we either fixed our own meals or ate in town rather than pay the inflated dinner prices at the Village.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: We have stayed at the Grand Waikikian several times and always find the property to be great. It is located on the huge grounds of the Hilton Village which has a variety of shops and activities available. The rooms in the Grand Wai are superior to the standard Hilton ones and worth the additional money. We usually stay in a one bedroom suite which has nice appointments and ample space for two. The kitchens are rather complete and are a good alternative to dining out if desired. The grounds have a variety of native Hawaiian fauna and flora and even some penguins to keep the kids entertained. The salt water lagoon offers a calmer alternative to the ocean and has ample beach for sun and fun. We always enjoy the Atlantis submarine trip and recommend that you spend the extra to get on the larger one as it is more spacious. There are many dining choices in the vicinity and we always enjoy Signha Thai at Ena and Ala Moana. They even have authentic Thai dances in the evening. Our favorite sushi place is a short cab ride to Doraku Sushi on Kalakaua Ave. Overall the Grand Wai has a lot to offer and is convenient to all of the fun in Waikiki.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: I had been to this property when it was first opened, and by myself, stayed in a 1 bedroom city view that looked out at the Illikai next door. This time, with 5 of us, we upgraded to a Premier 2 bedroom, our view was straight out to the gorgeous sunset, over the marina. We could watch surfers all day long, see the Friday night fireworks from the lanai (really loud echo off the Illikai). It was called a "corner ocean view" by the staff checking us into the hotel. I had read about a lack of service here, and found this trip it was completely the opposite experience for us, we were treated quite well, and anything we needed was ours by pressing one button on the phone. We were advised there would only be a midweek cleaning, as we were staying a week on my Hilton Grand Vacations Club points. We called a few days into the week and said we needed more towels & shampoo, they were there in minutes. When the technologically challenged 3 of us messed up the TV, we pressed the customer service button and about 30 minutes later we were helped by Joanne from Maintenance. She was great! She walked us through how to manage the TV, DVD player, stereo system, and channel 4, which is SO beautiful in the hotel! We looked down on the twice weekly luau and had that lovely music on the lanai at dinner time. Even the always shady lagoon pool was just below our room, and we watched the filming on Hawaii 5-0 from our deck one afternoon. We bought some beach chairs for $25 at the ABC store and used them the whole week, instead of paying $11 per day to rent a beach chair. Most days we sat at the Hilton Lagoon, which was warmer than both the ocean and the Ocean Pool at the Hilton (very cold). I rented a Paddle Board on the lagoon ($30 hr) and was a little bored after the first 20 minutes. A couple of times around the lagoon and you're done. It's is a great workout and the boards at the Hilton Lagoon are nice and new. Service at the Tropics bar and pool were excellent. Almost all the food served at the pool comes pre-packaged from the same place, the grab and go next to the Ocean Pool. Meals eaten onsite were very good, Tropics Bar (except one poor breakfast item), Japanese Restaurant in the Bazaar, Round Table Pizza and Lapperts Ice Cream were all excellent and not unreasonable priced. We walked almost everywhere, just minutes from the Ala Moana and it's excellent food court, We needed a cab to Pearl Harbor and the Diamond Head Trail, so location is great. We rented a car for a circle island trip one day, watched the surfers at Bonzai Pipeline and Makapu Beach. Yes, the resort is huge, there is a lot going on all the time, but if you are sitting out at the lagoon, you don't feel overcrowded at all. We were there a full week, everyone who worked in the hotel was very friendly and said Aloha as we walked by. I will mention that I do always travel with ear plugs, and this is one of those places you will need them. Honolulu has a lot of traffic noise, but there also is a plethora of things to keep you entertained. This condo oasis amid the hectic city is a perfect place to stay in Waikiki.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: This is a lovely hotel located int The Hilton Hawaiian village...great location on Waikiki beach and very serious shopping but really REALLY huge...a mini city unto itself with a ton of people, mostly from Asian countries so the Japanese food selection is FIRST CLASS sushi etc... Food very good but the pools are FREEZING and unheatead and interestingly very crowded since I swear they pour ice cubes in the pool at night! The pacific is also cold so if you have temperature issues (as I do ) swimming is difficult. Service is top notch...staff could not be more attentive which says a lot about the Hilton management as this is a very large complex and they do not let you feel invisible! Great little convenient stores on site with late hours that serve booze and food at all hours and perfectly located to all the good stuff n Honolulu ....

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: I have delayed in posting this review since my family of four (two girls aged 11 and 5) visited at Thanksgiving, thinking that the longer I wait, the better my attitude about our stay will be. Alas, it has been over a month and I just can't shake my overall poor impression. Which means that I will have to post this review despite the fact that we were upgraded to a three bedroom penthouse unit on the top floor. Now before you close this review in disgust about me, assuming that I am a prima donna who cannot be satisfied, let me disclose that I write from our $120/night room at the Residence Inn in Overland Park, KS where we are having a wonderful stay visiting family for the holidays. So I don't need any kind of over the top luxury to have a good time, but as the price creeps up, and when certain "amenities" appear to be present, then my expectations do change.So, we booked a two bedroom ocean view unit at the Grand Waikikian over Thanksgiving. About a week ahead of time, their travel coordinators called and helped answer all of my questions about the unit and the amenities at the hotel - I had several questions about the kids club, about the spa, about the other activities at the resort, and about other activities we had planned while on the island. She was so knowledgeable and friendly, taking so much time with me on the phone, that I was actually more excited about the trip after talking with her! We used the recommended hotel transportation company to book a car service to pick us up. The driver was terrific and gave us his card so he could take us back to the airport when we left the island. He charged literally HALF what we paid en route to the hotel. If you want his number, message me.We happened to mention just as we were approaching the Hilton Hawaiian Village that we were staying at the Grand Waikikian, and that is very important information since there are two different hotel entrances. Ask your driver to drop you off at the Grand Waikikian or you'll have to trek through the grounds with your bags, and as several other reviewers have indicated, no one who works at the resort knows where anything else is located, and the signs and maps are not precise enough to be helpful.Up to the point of arriving at the check-in line at the hotel, the whole experience was really wonderful even with the very expensive airport transfer. When we got out of the car, we were greeted by lovely smiling faces and kukui nut leis for everyone. The appearance of the check-in area is beautiful, and consistent with a full-service hotel. We waited for some time in the check-in line, even though there was only one family in front of us. When we finally got to the front of the line, the person checking in was very disoriented and typed madly into the computer for several minutes without any word or update (think of the scene in Honeymoon in Vegas when Nicolas Cage is trying to get a flight to Hawaii to win back Jennifer Aniston). She finally looked up and said, "It looks like you've been upgraded to a penthouse unit, so you can check in upstairs on the 35th floor if you want." I asked if we had to go to the 35th floor to check-in and she told us that we could check in there where we already were, but that we "might want to go to the 35th floor to check in." We flew 10 hours to get to Oahu from Atlanta and my wick was rather short, so I figured rather than ask her again to check us in, we would just go upstairs and check in where she seemed to want us to go. The trek to the 35th floor was long and arduous. The layout of the hotel is odd in that the main lobby is separated from the elevator bay that leads to rooms by two long hallways, lined by "concierge desks" that appear to be focused on sales of timeshare units. We finally got to the 35th floor and ended up spending at least 45 minutes getting checked in there because "they didn't have a record of our reservation," though I brought the printed confirmation with us and gave it to her. In the end, of course, we didn't complain since they upgraded us from a two bedroom to the most exquisitely beautiful three bedroom unit on the top floor.We figured that it would be nothing but smooth sailing from here. How bad can it be from the penthouse suite? Truthfully, our stay in Hawaii was wonderful, and of course we did enjoy our spacious suite very very much. The lanai facing out toward the ocean was absolutely delightful and naturally there is nothing to complain about AT ALL regarding the features of the suite. I have never before, and very likely never again will, stayed at a place as nice as that penthouse suite. The kids ADORED the Toto toilets/bidets.However, the niceness of the suite only served as a more stark contrast with the poor service provided by hotel staff. One example was when I called to find out about the kids program. I wanted to sign up my children for a session but was told that not only could they not tell me over the phone whether there was availability, but I had to physically walk all the way from the Grand Waikikian to the main Hilton Hawaiian Village check-in area to find out if they had availability and to sign up. Really? OK. So I walked all the way, only to find that all of the sessions we were interested in signing up for were already full. Another example occurred on our first morning there when we were looking for a place to have breakfast on the resort. We literally walked around for 25 minutes looking for the Rainbow Lanai, having asked three staff people that we bumped into, where to find it. We were either given incorrect directions or the staff people just didn't know. Several staff people milling about the main check in area saw us looking around clearly lost at 6:00am, but no one offered to help us. When we finally did find the breakfast place (it was temporarily in another building due to construction), we were extremely disappointed in the quality of the breakfast buffet. We paid $90 for our breakfast for two adults and two kids and the waffles were rock hard while the rest of the food was unremarkable at best. DO NOT EAT ON THE RESORT, except at Roundtable Pizza where you will get what you expect - greasy, decent pizza at only slightly elevated prices.. Best low cost and quick breakfast we found was the Wailana Coffee House across Ala Moana. Best breakfast buffet - about 20 minute walk with our five year old slow poke - was at the Moana Surfrider hotel. Before we fully learned not to eat at the resort, we ordered room service and once again were amazed at the gaping difference between food quality (very, very low) and price (very, very high). Another unsettling experience is the bus/shuttle terminal which serves the entire Hilton Hawaiian Village resort. I understand why they need to do this given the size of the resort, but there is an unmistakable air of being treated like chattel when one is waiting for a shuttle to an off-site activity (such as the Paradise Cove luau or our shuttle to Hanauma Bay to snorkle). Not to mention that it is a solid 15 minute walk from one's room at the Grand Waikikian to the bus pick up. It would actually be quicker and more convenient to arrange your pick-ups and drop-offs at the Ilikai Hotel which is right across the street from the Grand Waikikian. We got off at this stop when we returned from Paradise Cove and were in our room with our tired kids probably 20 minutes sooner than if we'd gone on to the Hilton Hawaiian Village stop.On top of all this is the ambiance created by their treat-customers-as-criminals approach regarding pool towels and wristbands, mentioned by other reviewers. Though we were upgraded to a suite we clearly could never afford to pay for at full price, we were still paying $650 per night for the two-bedroom suite we originally booked and so all of this poor service leads to a little bit of a bad taste in the mouth.The piece de resistance was that when we traveled to Oahu in November, the high temperatures outdoors were hovering right around 80 degrees. Not super hot. The one pool that my kids would want to play in - the one with the slides - was absolutely FREEZING. I couldn't even stand in the shallow one foot deep water for more than 10 minutes at a time. The hot tubs were overflowing with people - many of the children with visibly blue lips - and my kids ultimately didn't swim because they were too cold. The pool with slides does not get any direct sun at all throughout the day because it is located in the shadows between several buildings. They need to add a heater to that pool for it to be enjoyable. Luckily, we did play in the lagoon, renting stand up paddle boards two days in a row. Overall, I doubt we would return to any property at Hilton Hawaiian Village for all of these reasons. I am likely to look for adjoining rooms at a hotel closer to the action on Waikiki that will cost about the same as the suite at the Grand Waikikian. But especially in these economic times, I feel like I shouldn't settle for being treated this way when I am paying this much.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: We stayed in a one bedroom city view suite for four nights with our two small children (aged 2.5 years and 6 months). The room was clean and exactly as pictured on the internet, although it was smaller than I'd imagined, in particular the bathroom which was quite tight. Personally I disliked having a bath in the bedroom, but aside from this the suite was nice. Although we didn't cook the kitchen was perfect for breakfasts and the washer/dryer extremely useful. The hotel provided a crib for our son and our daughter slept on the sofa bed. While the main bed was quite comfortable the sofa bed was not and I wouldn't recommend any adults plan to spend too long sleeping there. Next time we would book a two bedroom suite based on this fact alone!The check-in service at the Grand Vacations was poor, with a very disinterested and unhelpful staff member at the desk. We had originally tried to check-in at the general Hilton Hawaiian Village reception as this was where we were ushered when we got out of our taxi (our driver didn't drop us at the Grand Waikikian, but rather the general entry point). The documentation sent by the hotel did not specify that we should check-in at the Grand Waikikian either - this wasn't a huge drama but I thought I would mention it to stop others from wasting 20 minutes standing in line at the wrong check-in desk.Our package included daily housekeeping. The service, when we received it, was ok. However, on one day the housekeeper arrived at 8 am so we sent her away as we just weren't ready. We did request fresh towels and for her to remove the rubbish from the room. As other reviewers mention, it isn't possible for housekeeping to return so if you send them away you should be aware of this.We also booked an airport transfer through the hotel. We clearly specified that we would need two baby seats (we checked this again when the front desk called to confirm the booking). We were quite disappointed and concerned when the taxi that arrived only had one seat (at 5 am with not a huge amount of time to spare for our flight we really didn't have many options available to us either). Again, it is difficult to ascertain whether this was the fault of the taxi company or the hotel, but no having a good relationship with a reputable taxi/car service seemed like another example of patchy service.Location wise, the Hilton Hawaiian Village is very convenient. It is a short walk to Ala Moana in one direction and to Waikiki in the other. The Village also has just about everything you might need in terms of food and entertainment and I am sure many people never venture through the gates. Obviously a place of this size is a bit soulless and if you prefer personalised attention and service this probably isn't the hotel to stay at.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: I stayed at the Hilton Grand Vacations timeshare resort in a one bedroom suite. I was booked originally in a studio in a neighboring building. When I saw the tiny studio I pleaded with management to give me something better and both managers Steve and Shiho went above and beyond to make my vacation a pleasant one. I ended up spending 8 days in the GW and it was lovely. The room seems very new, with hardwood floors, a living area, full kitchen, breakfast table, balcony with a view (depends on what room you are in), a sunken tub, a walk-in shower, a bedroom, free internet, daily newspaper, and no maid service. The kitchen comes equipped with all you need to cook, and there is a stove, fridge, icemaker, microwave and dishwasher. All appliances are very nice. The room was immaculate upon entry (not so much when we left!). The balcony was nice size, with a table and a few chairs and had a view of the mountains and downtown. The service was excellent across the boards. From checkin to the bellmen to housekeeping, everyone was professional, pleasant and efficient. Some of the people working in the restaurants and bars could have used a little training, but all in all, we were well taken care of. The resort is huge. There are seven or eight buildings, with three belonging to HGVC and the others part of the Hilton hotel. The place is overrun with foreign tourists. There is a shopping mall right in the resort with many stores, restaurants, Louis Vuitton, Starbucks, etc. It is very nice and convenient, and pretty pricey. There are four pools, all of which are nothing special. There is no sun protection in the way of umbrellas or shady areas, so that was an issue. Also, they are all very crowded and lots of screaming kids. There are a few nice beach bars and restaurants, and a very very nice lagoon on the property for swimming and boating. The hotel is right on the beach, and very nice. If you want an umbrella or chair, you'll pay dearly ($60 for two chairs and an umbrella). The downside is, everything is far. The gym is in the Kalia building, which is about a ten minute walk from us. There are a lot of aerobic machines, but not much else. The place was packed, with not a free machine, at 7am. The spa locker room and sauna costs $17 per day, but the gym is free. The spa woman was one of those "sour" ones that, when asked about the internet at the spa pool, responded, "we don't issue that kind of information." With the size of the place, you'd think that they'd train the staff to help visitors find things, but constantly, when asking a staff member where something was located, they never knew where anything was or how to get there. That was very strange. The grounds, pools, beaches were all immaculately clean and beautiful. At the pools, you are required to wear wrist bands and turn in cards for towels. If you lose the cards before checkout, you pay $10 per card lost fee. I found it a bit irritating, but they do it to keep non-guests out and I can understand that. The center of Waikiki is a 15 minute stroll, or a $5 cab ride, but there are plenty of dining choices nearby and inside the hotel. There are amazing upscale malls everywhere, with multiple designer stores from every high end brand you can think of. Since I was upgraded I felt the value was good for me. If I were to pay $650 or so for this room on this property, I might be a little upset. There are many beautiful luxury resorts in the center that I would select before this one. However, if you are traveling with kids, like the hubbub of a big resort, then Hilton is the one. All in all, a great place to stay if you can afford it and don't mind being a bit outside the center.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: I stayed here for a conference. The hotel is very beautiful, but the grounds are overwhelming (its like a college campus!). Takes a while to get your bearings. Great pool(s), but some of the worst customer service I've ever had at any hotel, ever. I was meeting some friends at the Tapas bar and it was clear that the waitress was overworked, which I am sympathetic to. When she finally did come over, I asked if I could order some food to which she responded "All we have is pizza and that's gonna take well over 45 minutes". Um, way to sell it. Additionally, when I returned home I thought I had left something in my room. I called and after being inadvertently disconnected several times and calling back, the woman responded (clearly irritated) "OK,it's like 5 in the morning here. You're gonna have to call back later". These are just a cople examples of the poor attitude and service.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: Part of the Hilton Hawaiian Village, the Grand Waikikian is the newest and so furthest from the beach and resort restaurants and activities. However, it is adjacent to the waterslides and lagoon which make it ideal for families with children. No table service or snack bar so be sure to bring some with you.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: We visited the Grand Waikikian for a week as a part of our honeymoon vacation. I have traveled alot and this has to be one of the best hotels I have been to. It is located within the Hilton Hawaian Village in Honolulu. The Hilton village is comprised of various hotels / restaurants / & shops....it is essentially a mini city. The property has 4 pools & a lagoon which all guests have access to & the beach is amazing. The best part of this hotel is the built in kitchens in each room. Since Hawaii is not an "all inclusive" it can get expensive. We would visit the local foodland grocery store and buy some meals / snacks to prepare / eat in our room. Bacon / eggs / toast / & juice would be our breakfast in the mornings and we got a few frozen pizza's for snacks during the day. Every evening we would visit the famous Waikiki strip and splurge on dinner.The Waikiki strip of shops / restaurants / & clubs is only a 5-10 min walk away through the park. It is extremely safe and we never encountered any problems walking to or from the hotel. There is an endless amount variety in regards to food. I would suggest Hy's Steakhouse / Cheesecake Factory / & Dukes (located in the outrigger hotel).In my opinion this hotel offers the best of both worlds. During the days we would relax at the beach / pool and at night we had a great selection of food & nightlife to choose from.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: I've stayed at the Hilton Hawaiian Village before a very long time ago but not the building of the Grand Waikikian. Its part of the Hilton time-share, so we stayed there due to my friend's time share. But apparently you can still get a room there without a time share. Its a great room. Has a kitchen with everything you may need for a kitchen to function properly. It has a separate living room with a tv and great sound system and dvd player. It has a balcony, but unfortunately ours was facing the city not the beach. The bathroom was large. There's a tub in the bedroom, and another tv in the bedroom. I can't complain at all about the room. But since we were using timeshare, we were informed that if we want our room cleaned it would be an extra $50 I think per day. We decided not to do that, and decided just to keep our room clean ourselves. You can ask though for extra toiletries from housekeeping free of charge. You get these cards to be able to get a beach towel when your at the beach, and have to make sure to return it when you check out. You also get a card to be able to rent free dvd's at the dvd kiosks around the lobby. There is extra charge for parking and valet. We opted for valet since I think the price difference was like a few dollars only. You have to pay extra for a beach bed and umbrella if you want one on the beach. I find that the most ridiculous thing I've ever heard before. And its not a one time fee for your stay, its a daily fee of I think $25 for a beach bed and another I don't know for the umbrella. I couldn't believe it. I mean when do you go to beach resort and be charged extra to be able to stay at the beach when your a paying guest. I could understand if your just a beach wanderer, but a guest of the hotel? They said its to keep track of their beach beds and umbrellas cause they've lost a lot, but really. If you found a system for the beach towels, why not find a better system for the beach bed and umbrellas. We tried laying on the sand with just our beach towels but didn't last long cause the sand would still burn our toes if it hit it. So we moved by the pool area, because the beach beds and umbrellas were free to use there, you just need to wear this bracelet that they give you upon check in so they know your a guest of the hotel. I understand why they have to protect themselves, their location is truly great, and I'm sure there are freeloaders from other places that pretend they are guests and use all their amenities, but I think they have to find a better way to treat their real guests and make them truly feel like their guest is in paradise. It just ruins the whole experience. All these extras that shouldn't be extras. Without all these little frustrations, there is really no need to leave this place. The restaurants around are great. They have shops in the area, including an ABC which is the same price as the ABC outside the hotel, they didn't jack up the prices, so you can buy whatever you need for the kitchen. I really want to love this place, and I did before, but I just didn't like the extras for every little thing.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: Firstly, the room is nice; however, we expect a lot more from a Hilton, especially for the price of this one. A/C is not cold...maintenance came in twice and told us that it was the best they could do and we should close our shades. We did close our shades and it lowered the temperature from 77 to 75...still not even room temperature. 1+ hour to deliver toilet paper...usually when somebody requests toilet paper, it's at least somewhat immediate. And, probably the most disappointing is the "partial" ocean view. Don't shell out $$ for this room. We're staring smack dab at downtown Honolulu, but if we go to the edge of our deck and lean over (which is quite dangerous on the 23rd floor), then we catch a tiny glimpse of a dock with some boats and some water. Overall, just very disappointing for the money.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: I stayed at the Grand Waikikian for one week with family ... a group of four adults and two small children. We were in a two bedroom, two bath, full kitchen city view room. All in all, we had a great time at the Grand Waikikian, and if you want to vacation at a resort in Honolulu, this timeshare-hotel-resort can't be beat. However, there are a number of tradeoffs that you make when you stay at the Hilton Grand Waikikian.The Room. Overall, we were very pleased with the room. Clean, and very functional. We particularly liked the breakfast bar/counter where our kids could eat and do their little projects. The dining table was also a diner-style booth that easily seated five people, but was never in the way like a true dining table. The master bathroom did not have a separate bathroom ... the soaking bathtub, the shower, and the sink was adjacent to the bedroom with no wall or door separating it. I personally don't like this layout because it doesn't separate the sleeping quarters with the bath area. The room also had all sorts of electronic toys including a PlayStation 3 and DVD players. There's even a free RedBox style DVD rental machine in the lobby so you can get movies and games to entertain yourself.The Facilities. The Hilton Hawaiian Village is essentially a self-contained resort adjacent to Waikiki. The TV show Hawai'i 5-0 uses it frequently as a backdrop. There's a small mall, lots of restaurants, an artificial salt-water lagoon, and of course a sandy beach. There are even penguins and flamingos for your entertainment. The best part of our experience was the pools. There's a new pool complex adjacent to the Waikikian that includes two hot tubs, and three water slides, including one that's totally appropriate for toddlers. It's a fantastic play area for small children. The complex also has a free fireworks show on Friday nights on the beach. Get takeout dinner, and have a picnic on the beach while you wait for the great show. Finally, the self-parking lot is a challenge. It's not large enough for a resort complex of this size, so you unfortunately end up needing to valet, unless you want to spend a material portion of your vacation hunting for parking.There are unfortunately several considerations that make the Grand Wakikian a marginal experience at luxury hotel prices. First and foremost, I felt like I was being nickeled and dimed everywhere. I needed to keep track of plastic cards to get pool towels or suffer a $10 surcharge. I needed to wear a wrist band to get into the pool. There's no food service at the pools, but there was a ton of security like people telling us what we could not do. And there were a number of housekeeping / upkeep "misses", not the least of which was the garbage that was collecting on the window ledges, including several cigarette packs. I really don't want to see garbage when I sit on the lanai (patio). Finally, there's a bit of a disconnect between the price and the service. The price was luxury, but the service was just "average Hilton". Not bad service, but I was expecting better for the price.Then there's the location. On paper, it looks great ... close to Waikiki, close to Ala Moana Shopping center. But unfortuately, it's not close enough to be truly walkable to either places. So you need to take the bus or taxi, or get a car and suffer the parking issues. And you definitely need a car if you want to go to a grocery store or a big-box retailer for basics. Of course, this is not a problem if you are using the Grand Waikikian and the Hilton Hawaiian Village as a self-contained resort. BUT, if you want a self-contained resort, there are a lot of other choices on O'ahu and the other Hawaiian Islands that are frankly better choices. That is the tradeoff with the Grand Waikikian ... you pay for the privilege of being in the heart of Honolulu, which is a great city with a lot of things to explore and experience. If this isn't a priority, you have many other options to consider.In summary, if you want to stay in a new fully-equipped one or two bedroom hotel in the heart of Honolulu, you can't go wrong with the Grand Waikikian. Just understand that you are paying for that privilege.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: We enjoyed our spacious two bedroom suite with a fabulous view overlooking lagoon and ocean. Each morning we enjoyed our coffee on the lanai while watching surfers and boats traffic in and out of the harbor. Unlike the loud party scene of Waikiki Beach, we enjoyed the peaceful atmosphere of Hilton Hawaiian Village. We had a short walk along the beach to the night life of Waikiki when we wanted, and peace the rest of the time.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: We stayed at the HGVC in Las Vegas and loved the accomodations so we booked a mini vacation to the Grand Waikikian. We loved it so much that we actually bought into the HGVC (more on that later).ACCOMODATIONS: This is definitely a nice hotel. Clean, nicely decorated, and has a well equipped full-kitchen and a washer and dryer. Make sure to ask for suppies for the week when you call down to the desk (coffee, laundry soap, dishwasher soap, pillows, towels, etc.). Otherwise, you'll be tipping out the yang for people to bring them to you everyday. We had a 2 bedroom suite. The master bedroom has it's own bathroom/soaking tub, but that room does NOT have any windows that open to the exterior and the thermostat is regulated by the temperature of the rest of the condo. The 2nd room has a bathroom next to it (just outside the room) w/a shower and no tub. That room has a slider to the exterior which is nice for fresh air. HOWEVER, if that slider or the slider to the living area is open, the A/C turns off (SMART A/C system). Thus...causing a "sauna" situation for the master bedroom. Both bedrooms had king beds and the living room had a sofa sleeper (both rooms and the living room have TV's). There's a ceiling fan in the living area which is nice for sleeping. There was a video gaming system in the living area but we didn't use it. There is also WiFi that you have to pay for unless you are a HGVC owner, then they provide you w/a password. I think it was $10 a day but since we were there on a "promotional" mini vacation, they waived the fee for us.LOCATION: This hotel is in a SUPERB location. It is walking distance from the International Market as well as "high dollar" shopping. The hotel has it's own lagoon which is great for snorkeling, etc. There aren't any waves so don't expect to body surf and and the "beach" around it isn't great unless you have chairs. It's pretty compacted (hard) similar to a decomposed granite track (like that which surrounds a football field). The actual beach is just beyond the lagoon and you can walk up and down it to other hotels, bars, restaurants, etc. The pool is fabulous with a water slide for the kids. Not as nice or as big as the one in Waikoloa (on the big island of Hawaii). Towels cans be checked out but make sure you return them by the end of the day or you will be charged. Also, check w/the bellhops...they have all types of goodies in their luggage closet that people purchased and then left behind (styrofoam ice chests, chairs, boogie boards, etc.). TRANSPORTATION: In my opinion, you really don't need a car unless you want to drive around the island. We booked a dive trip but the company came and picked us up at the hotel (many of the excursions include transportation). If you do have a car, parking can be a challenge and can be costly. We rented a car because we got a killer deal so we parked in the parking structure in the adjacent military hotel and it was reasonable with in/out privileges.DINING: Food and alchoholic beverages cost an arm and a leg so we did some shopping off site and ate most of our meals in the room (plus we got some pre-mixed Mai Tai and Pina Colada mix...we'd make drinks and then take them down to the pool). Most of the dining in the "village" was very high priced but if you walk a block or two, there's plenty of reasonably priced places to eat. Hawaii is big on "plate" meals and noodle bowls. We also found this great Itallian place on one of the side streets across from the hotel...the owner is a nice older gentleman that was standing at the main intersection there handing out flyers and giving "tourism" tips...LOTS of tourism tips;-)THINGS TO DO: We've been to Hawaii many times so we hit the activities desk to see what other fun things they had to offer. We are divers so we did a combination SCUBA/SNUBA trip. My daughter wasn't certified so she did SNUBA (they float the air tank on a raft and have 20 ft hoses with regulators. It's like SCUBA diving but w/o all the equipment on your back and you only go down as far as your hose allows). If you haven't been to Diamond Head, you have to do it at least once. It's a great hike but it's not too difficult. I wouldn't take small kids...you can't take a stroller or anything since there are stairs...LOTS and lots of stairs. There's zip-lining, para-sailing, snorkeling...you name it (but you also pay for it!!!). Nothing is cheap in Hawaii, that's for sure. We chose to borrow some boogie boards and take our snorkeling gear to the other side of the island. One day we hit the military beach where they rent out bungalos (you have to have military I.D. though) and had a blast. Beautiful sandy beaches, lifeguard tower, convenience store...We also stopped at Laniakea Beach one day (the locals call it "turtle beach" and it's outside Haleiwa on Waialua Bay). It's not very visible from the road and you'll miss it if you don't know where it is because it's not one of the main beach parks, but it's great. Turtles everywhere...just remember, it's a huge fine if you touch a turtle...they are a protected species now. You can look at video and photos that people have posted on Trip Advisor by searching Laniakea Beach or by going to this link: http://tripwow.tripadvisor.com/slideshow-photo/laniakea-beach-turtle-beach-oahu-hawaii-by-travelpod-member-bakasyonista-oahu-united-states.html?sid=11529042&fid=tp-9&supkl=kl&m=10995&supkw=%22Turtle+beach%22+oahu

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: We took my family of 5 to stay at the Grand Waikikian for 3 nights in a 1 bedroom suite. The room had everything you could need - stove, microwave, coffee maker, DVD player, Playstation 3, and hot tub. My kids (3, 5, 12) loved the free DVD rentals. They have a great swimming pool with a water slide for the kids. It was a close walk to the beach - not exactly right outside the door but maybe 5 minutes away. The Hilton property is huge with lots of things to do. They had penguins and flamingos. At 8am Monday thru Friday you can go down to the penguin area for a ltitle talk about the penguins and they let you touch one of the penguins and feed the turtles. This was our second time back and we'll definetly be back again next year. In addition, there's a hospitality room for people who want to shower/freshen up before leaving the facilities. This allows you to enjoy the beach and still be able to shower after checkout. The hospitality area even has free beverages and pastries, and toiletiries.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: We stayed here last week and liked it. Someone else wrote about the noise and that's so true. And that beeping in the morning - sounds like a backup bell but louder. Just the traffic, I guess. Hard to tell just what the noise is - not people. But, with your door closed, you don't hear it. We had two queen size beds and a nice view of the ocean from bed. The living room had a couch that made into a bed, too. Nice furnishings and a TV in both the living room and bedroom. Our view was directly across from Hawaiian Village Tapa Tower but you still had a wonderful view of the ocean and a beautiful view of the city behind at night. We were in room 2909 and it had a great bathroom with both shower and tub and a nice kitchen. You could cook meals here if you were so inclined. If you want to bring your own coffee or buy coffee there, bring cone filters. Otherwise, you can use the coffee they supply in the packages with the coffee already in the filter. This is part of the Hilton Hawaiian Village and is right on the same property. A nice lobby but a long walk to the elevators. On their website the map shows the property across Ala Moana Blvd but it isn't. I'm glad that someone wrote about the lounge chairs at the Paradise pool that are turned around toward the lagoon - they were great. Be sure to try the Wailuna Coffee Shop across the street. Walk out through the HHV shopping area, past Benihana, to the street and turn left. The coffee shop is straight ahead across Ala Moana Blvd. We tried to get there from our hotel's back door but it wasn't a good way. The ABC store on the property has everything you need, even wine. Beautiful grounds with lots of lawn area. Starbucks. Be sure to get cookies at the Cookie Store. Delicious. Nice stay.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: Stayed on property April 2010 and came back in July 2011 b/c we had a great time previously. One bedroom condo worked well for family of 4. Differences this time was the obvious wear and tear of the furniture with hand prints, smears, and pencil graffiti on the walls. Definitely needs new paint. Management tried to cover up wear and tear with a foam cushion on bottom of the TV stand! We know b/c we were there when they installed it. Shower stall had black mold (?) in the corners. The bad=employees do not smile much or acknowledge you. The good=PS 3 and free daily movie or game rentals from kiosks (new feature), pools, fireworks on Friday night. Definitely would recommend getting a rental car. Save money drive past hotel entrance and park at meter. Paid $12 for 24 hr vs $26 on property. No "in and out" privileges at meter though. U can pay for 1-24 hrs increments. Much easier to get to the car vs parking structure on property. Able to stop by Costco which is close by the air port to pick up snacks, water, etc. Save few $$ by eating breakfast and lunch in room with microwave, toaster, etc. Try to visit North shore, Shark cove for snorkling, Giovanni shrimp truck, and definitely Kailua Beach Park (has bathroom, showers, life guards) and nearby Lanikai Beach. No need to go to Cancun for white fine sand and clear blue waters.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: Just returned from our 25th wedding anniverary in Hawaii and had an amazing time!! We have visited Oahu many times and the Grand Waikikian is our FAVORITE place to stay. Location is wonderful and is a part of the Hilton Hawaiian Village (which is a mini vacation all its own, shops, restaurants, conveniences) Rooms range from a studio to 3bdrm suites, which means cozy for two or spread out spacious for a whole family!! Check in greets you with orchid leis for the ladies and kukui nut leis for the men. It is a busy hotel with constant arrivals and departures, but rooms are quiet as a church mouse, which is a lovely feature all its own!! Rooms are generously appointed, neat and tidy, equiped with fully functioning kitchens and housewares!It is withing walking distance to Lewers Street (shopping, restaurants) and International Marketplace. If you are connected to the military, the Hale Koa is right next door and offers you extra savings, shopping, facilities etc...Landscaping is gorgeous and the pools (and even a lagoon) are plentiful and its all right on the beach if you'd rather sand with your sun...The Hilton Grand Waikikian makes paradise just a bit more heavenly!! :o) If you want a visual, visit www.hgvc.com and click on explore resorts--HAWAII, enjoy!!

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: This our 3rd trip back to Waikiki and definately the BEST. What a great resort with everything at your doorstep from restaurants to pools to the beach and lagoon.Yes other resorts say go use the lagoon and beach.. at the Waikikian it is at your doorstep.Yes it is more expensive than some other resorts but we stayed in a 2 bedroom suite and it was fantastic. In a resort view room we had a great water view still from our lanai and right beside the lagoon and pool with slides for us all to enjoy not just the kids.The surf guys Kane and Mike were sensational and had lessons with my wife and 3 boys was such a great experience and the guys were great...The resort is a class above, rooms, activities, location, luau and total experience. Not exactly for the budget minded however you don't have to spend there if you don't want to.We loved it and will definately be returning to the Garnd Waikikian Suites...

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: We stayed on 30th floor of the Grand Waikikian tower. There are 7 towers in the Hilton Hawaiian Village. There are plenty of activities to do. The weight room is like any hotel fitness room. (Our vacation started at the Four Seasons in Maui at Wailea. They have an excellent weight room that allows you to target every muscle group plus they have yoga classes, Zumba classes, Hip Hop classes, and body sculpt classes.) There are no fitness classes at Hilton Hawaiian Village. We took the Lei Making class and the Hula Dance class. Both were fun! We witnessed the penguin feeding time, but couldn't hear what the trainer was saying. I wished she would have been wearing a microphone so that we could hear about the 7 penquins and what they look for when they are feeding them, etc. Too many little kids surrounding the penguins. Great shopping on the hotel grounds! I loved selecting the oyster and getting not one, but two pearls at the Maui Divers Jewelry store for $14.95. Then you can have it mounted if you like. This was my favorite souvenir from Hawaii.The beach was beautiful. We took surf lessons at the hotel. I never knew how much upper body strength it takes to surf! But, true to their word, the four of us (ages 48, 49, 21, and 18) stood up and surfed.We attended the Luau on Thursday night. We paid extra for the premier seating. They tell you that if you have little kids it is better closer than farther. Since we are all adults, that was not a concern. We still chose the premier seating and it pays off when it is time to go up to the buffet line. The tables are called up and they start with premier seating. Plus, the premier seating gets a flower and a coral lei. We thought going early to eat was worth the extra $20/person. The food was good. The dessert was so-so. The entertainment was great! The drink guys worked incredibly hard.We also attended the dinner starlight cruise with fireworks viewing from the catamaran boat. We dressed up, and wished we had worn jeans or casual clothes. We didn't know. The food was okay. The dessert (mini cheese cakes and creme puffs) was great! The staff was fun and one of the blue-eyed, blond crew members, Josh, was fluent in Japanese!The Pronto Pickle has some great sandwiches and Lapperts serves great ice cream and shakes.The grounds were beautifully kept. There seemed to be a wedding every day. The Hilton has a cute little church. It is an awesome place to get married. We walked from Hilton to the other end of the beach. Great exercise then, we walked down the shopping street. Everyone has a store on this road. I think it beats the Magnificent Mile in Chicago.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: When we go to Oahu, we never fail to stay at HGVC. My Shell Vacations Club timeshare gives me privileges to exchange next door at the Ilikai (I should have bought at the Hilton) but why stay there, when this is ten times more superior? The Grand Waikikian is the latest addition to the HGVC properties. Advantages: closer to the waterfront, more modern appliances, own back entrance which is closer to the street, access to the water slides pool - our suite gave us a view of the rooftop luau show, close to the boarding lessons at the lagoon area. Minuses: don't get the corner suites -- seem smaller with less oceanfront views, the cold, cold air conditioning in the lobby, pricey.This property is definitely for you if:- you want to save money by cooking meals in a full kitchen- you like the apartment experience and need your space but still have hotel amenities at your fingertips- you like to hang out in your suite, relax and soak in the views and the breezes - you like your own beachfront (the umbrella fees are horrible!) - you like to walk a few steps to shops and a variety of hotel restaurants.- you like to have supervised entertainment for your kids- you want a clean, well-maintained top notch propertyTIPS: Shop for food at Costco or Ala Moana Center -Foodland or pre-cooked Asian food at Shiryoka - top floor. Go to the military hotel next door to the fast food deli by the beach for $3.50 hot dogs instead of the $10 ones at HGVC property. DVD rental kiosks in the lobby are good for chilling out at night.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: Just came in today. So far, not very impressed. I brought my family here with a time share sale deal. I upgraded the package to stay in a two bedroom fully furnished and equipped unit. Hilton Grand Vacations at check in would not honor my Hilton Honors gold status with resort vouchers that I typically would use for breakfast. They told me that since I was staying with Grand Vacations and not Hilton, they would not honor my Gold Status. After checking in, the unit is ok. The A/C doesn't seem to be workiing up to par. It's quite warm in here. The master bath has a seperate shower, tub, and sink. Guess what, we get two bars of soap! The dresser is attached to the wall. It looks like it weighs a ton or so, but they see the need to user straps to tie it to the wall. A piece of trim in the master bedroom bath area appears as if it is about to pop off the wall, and this is a new building! These may seem like trivial issues, but remember, Hilton is trying to convince me to buy one of their timeshares. So far, no way! Like I said, the jury is out. Still to early to render a final review of this property.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: We loved having our own kitchen and washer/dryer while being in Honolulu. Units are very new and clean. Also, units are very quiet. We felt right at home. The only glitch we experienced was at check-in. Our reservation was lost do to misspelling our last name. After a brief delay, we were found.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: This was my 4th trip to the Hilton Hawaiian Village but my first in the Hilton Grand Vacation Club. We booked a timeshare promotion for the HGVC. We stayed in the Grand Waikikian towers and it was absolutely beautiful!! Even better than in the pictures. It was like having a small (luxury) apartment. Our unit faced a main street but it didn't stop us from having meals on our balcony daily. We slept with the balcony door open for the breeze but the hotel-provided clock radio was also a sound machine that played soothing water sound. We use one at home for our toddler to sleep so I packed my ipod and docking station for nothing. I know for next time!It was perfect for my 2 year old to run around in and we didn't feel crowded. We usually rent suites with kitchens or vacation rentals but this was like having a vacation rental plus the added bonus of top notch hotel amenities. The customer service is outstanding as well. My daughter threw her pants off the balcony... twice (Luckily they just landed on the patio of the room below ours)! Both times they were quickly retrieved by hotel staff.One of the pools is a salt water pool and my daughter LOVED it. It's much gentler than chlorine. There are waterfalls, water slides, a lagoon, fireworks and flamingos in the "village"! I LOVE this hotel. This is by far the best hotel in Waikiki for families with young children.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: We visited the Hilton Hawaiian Village on a marketing package. For $1,200 plus 2 hours of our time one afternoon for a timeshare sales pitch we got 6 nights in a city view 1 bedroom condo in the Grand Waikikian Tower, plus free mid-size car rental and a $200 certificate toward a future Hilton stay. I'll talk about the marketing package at the end of the review.The room was nice, spacious, and comfortable. I was very excited that our city view balcony had an ocean view from one side- we were on the 28th floor in an end room (2811). However, it was very windy on the balcony when the trade winds were blowing and there was lots of street noise (even from the 28th floor), so we didn't spend much time out there. In fact, we spent very little time in the room overall, but the elevators were fast, the room was clean, the bathroom spacious, the shower pressure good, the bed firm but comfortable, the bedding and towels nice, and the kitchen, though we didn't end up using it, was very nice and seemed to have what you would need. As it is a timeshare you only get housekeeping 1x during your stay, but if you need anything in between you can request it. It was also nice to have a washer and dryer. Yes, the resort is enormous - it is truly a village. If you don’t care to walk don’t stay here. Amazingly while it accommodates 5,000 people and has 1,800 staff, it never felt crowded. The grounds are amazingly gorgeous with winding paths, ponds, waterfalls, koi, flamingos, penguins, swans, and gardens. You will do a lot of walking on concrete both on the resort and exploring Waikiki - I ended up going to the Ala Moana Center to buy some sandals with better support as my feet were throbbing by day 2 from my cute sandals. Bring some comfortable (but still cute!) sandals with a good sole.The pools are very nice. We started at the super pool the first day, as I thought the paradise pool would have too much noise since it's the fun pool for kids. Unfortunately the super pool doesn't have an ocean view, so I wasn't overly excited about it. Here's my #1 review tip if you don't have kids and a pool chair with a good view is important to you: the back row of pool chairs at the paradise pool are turned around to face the lagoon and the Pacific beyond. They're easy to get as most people have kids and need to be closer to the pool (we got them any time we wanted, even arriving early afternoon), the view of the lagoon and ocean is beautiful, and the noise from the pool wasn't bad (and I don't like noise). Plus, two out of the six days a kid puked in the pool, which requires them to shut it down for a few hours or the rest of the day. Gross, yes, but with a great side-benefit for us: suddenly all the kids and their parents exit for the other pools, and you're left with a great view and absolute peace and quiet - and you still have the lagoon steps away to cool off in! Another tip - they give you bracelets to wear when at the pool when you check in - don't worry about it (put them in your bag) - no one wears them and we never got asked. And be sure to go down the bigger waterslide – it was surprisingly fun!Waikiki Beach is beautiful. We didn’t sit on the beach, but we walked it every morning and several times during the day. It gets very busy as the day goes on but the beach in front of the Hilton is wide and isn’t crowded like the Diamond Head end of the beach. I didn’t think I’d like the Hilton’s lagoon but I loved it. It’s beautiful and fun to walk around and swim in. There’s also a nice wide concrete path (the beachwalk) from the Hilton to down past the Sheraton.We ate and/or had cocktails at Tropics several times, got sandwiches from Pronto Pickle, hot dogs from the little place at the base of the rainbow tower, and had Kona coffee and pastries from Lappert's coffee shop each morning. Yes they are all expensive, but so is almost everything in Waikiki. We had great burgers next door at the Hale Koa Military hotel (cafeteria style ordering then take your tray out to the bar/patio tables on the beach - you don't have to be military to eat there) and that is much cheaper - $18 for two burgers, fries, and cokes. A gallon of water for your room is $4.99 at the Accents gift shop in the GW tower, which I noted was only 50 cents more than the ABC store at the mall. Overall, expect to pay $8.50/beer, $10/cocktail, $15-$18 for an appetizer or sandwich, and $25-$35 for an entree - at the Hilton or most places in Waikiki. One recommendation is Tiki's at the other end of Waikiki for their Calamari Katsu appetizer - it is amazing. Rum Fire at the Sharaton also had a great atmosphere mid-evening for tapas.One thing I have to rave about is the service on check-out day. Checkout is at 11, but you can still use all of the hotel amenities for the rest of the day (your key still works to get into the pool area, you can get towels, etc). As a guest of HVC you can use the spacious concierge area of the GW Tower until 5 pm. It has painfully slow Internet, light refreshments, lots of sitting areas, and showers. We had an 11 pm flight, so we packed our bags, put them in the car, then sat by the pool all day. We didn’t want to shower by 5, so instead of the concierge room we used one of the hotel’s hospitality rooms. You can make a reservation for one at the main hotel front desk, and at your reserved time they will give you a key to a regular hotel room that you can use for 20 minutes per adult (I’m not sure what they do if you have kids). This was FANTASTIC – if it weren’t for this (or the concierge room) we wouldn’t have sat by the pool the last day – who wants to fly home covered in sunscreen and salt? The only minor frustration we had was right when we arrived. The signage at the Hilton is understated and tasteful so we had a hard time finding where to go once we were in the resort. We pulled up to the GW front desk after we finally found it, got checked in, then made our way back to the parking ramp – not really ever sure that we were in the right place. Once we got parked we had no idea how to get back to the GW tower from within the ramp - there's no signage in the ramp at all. If you're staying in the GW Tower go to level two on the opposite side of ramp from the elevators to a small section that seems like private parking with a shiny floor - a small almost unmarked door within that section will take you to into the GW tower. It's probably a staff entrance, but it's the only easy way back to the tower we found the whole week! Also, parking is $24 a day (which is probably why they give you the free rental car!), and some reviews recommend parking at the Hale Koa. It’s a long walk – spend the extra $8 per day.Some other random tips: Get an air mattress for $3.50 (includes inflating) at the ABC store and float in the lagoon. On your last day offer it to someone else. Venture out of Waikiki! Kayaking in Kailua was our highlight, and even if kayaking doesn't interest you go over there and spend some time on the beach to get away from the hustle and bustle of the city. Bring your GPS or rent one with your car - signage is HORRIBLE if it even exists and streets change names constantly. Even if you don't want to hike it, go to base of Diamond Head - there's a little cart that sells fresh pineapple spears for $3.00 a bag. It's wonderful and you can eat them right out of the baggie without getting sticky. If you venture toward Waianae stop at the Marriott in Ko'Olina for lunch - their beach restaurant overlooks the beautiful beach and lagoon and my husband is still raving about the fish tacos. (The Marriott itself was beautiful too if you’re looking for a nice place to stay out of Waikiki). If you're driving to the North Shore stop quick at the Dole Plantation to get a pineapple carving knife for $6 (works wonderfully) and try a dish of the Dole Whip (pineapple soft serve). It's right off the highway and is actually pretty cool. Also, “Oahu Revealed” is a GREAT guidebook written by locals. I’ve used it and the Maui one three times now and wouldn’t go without it.Be prepared when you go to Waikiki that it’s a major city. There are people everywhere, lots of street noise, heavy traffic, sirens, airplanes overhead, lines for restaurants, etc. If you are looking for peace and quiet go somewhere else – another part of the island or to another island altogether. The street noise does not extend to the pools or the beach, though there are people everywhere (again, without feeling crowded). In exchange you get a vibrant area to explore with tons of restaurant, shopping, and activity choices within walking distance. It’s also beautifully done – tiki torches light the beachwalk and restaurant patios at night, there are abundant gardens, trees, and parks , and the sea green ocean is breathtaking. Know what you’re going for - if you envision a week of absolute peace and quiet you are likely going to be disappointed.One final discussion about the “marketing package” as I was a bit nervous about it. It went without a hitch. I booked our April week in August after finding a good flight deal – the booking was easy. Our concierge called us the week before departure to confirm the details of our trip. Our car rental was easy to get. Check in was painless. We had a meeting with our concierge the first day we were there which I was sure would be another sales pitch – it wasn’t. She gave us some good tips (and some trinkets) and was fun to talk to – and didn’t try to sell us a thing. One note – the folder they give you with info on the island/resort has your $200 Spend a Night on Us certificate in it – don’t throw it away with the folder before you leave like I did.  The 2-hour sales pitch was not bad. I was actually interested in what they had to offer and considered it. If you think it may be for you research it before you go – if you’re going to buy you have to buy while you’re there and of course they give you extras/deals that you can only get if you sign while you’re sitting in the meeting. Also consider your financing before you go and know that it’s not just something you can generally go back to your bank and get a loan for as there’s really no collateral (I’m a banker). For the presentation your sales rep walks you through the program (it’s a points program), asks you a bunch of questions about your travel style, shows you a movie, answers your questions, etc. It’s a sales pitch but it’s not high pressure. If you say no her boss has to come in and offer a few more incentives. If you still say no they get a little short with you, but oh well. Be on your way and enjoy the rest of your week! It was well worth the value of the vacation deal.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: The Grand Waikikian is a great choice - It is back off the beach about a 100 yards but you still have a great view. Our only drawback was the the workout facility - it is in another buiding and sub par and crowded. If you are staying a week, hit the local grocery store - A Food Pantry is within walking distance of 2-3 blocks and load up on the basics.For those that like to get in a nice jog in the morning, head towards the Honolulu Zoo before 6am (its starts to get crowded at 7am) and enjoy the view. It is about 1.6 miles to the zoo - A nice 5k in the morning.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: We just returned from our vacation in Hawaii. We stayed in a 2BR penthouse suite in the Grand Waikikian while in Oahu. Our group was 2 couples, so the suite was a great choice.
