We both had our own bedroom and bath. We had room # 3611. Overall, the suite was very large with high-end finishings and furnishings. A very large LR with a balcony with ocean views, a DR area with round table. Kitchen with granite countertops and stainless steel appliances (would have been great if I wanted to spend my vacation cooking!) The master bedroom was very spacious with a balcony the full length of the room and bath. Our room had a great view of Diamondhead. The bathroom had a glass shower, toilet room and large whirlpool bath. There is a hallway with closet and washer/dryer combo. (Note: the washer & dryer take a LONG time to do a load. Not sure why, but allow 2 hours for each/load.) There is a door to separate the 2nd bedroom area. The bath is in the hall and also has a large whirlpool tub and glass shower. The 2nd bedroom has a queen bed and full length glass windows along both walls of the corner. The best thing about being in the penthouse is the penthouse lounge only for penthouse rooms. They have continental breakfast in the morning and happy hour in the evening. The suite personnel are wonderful and had great suggestions of where to go and what to do. It takes a lot of HGVC points for the penthouse, but if you figure in the savings for breakfast/appetizers/drinks it isn't too bad. We felt it was well worth the splurge! The Hilton property is very large and there is a lot of walking, but doable. There are two beaches and a couple pools. I preferred the "real" beach as opposed to the lagoon area. Be advised, if you want an umbrella and chair on the beach you need to pay for it. The chairs are $15.71, not sure about the umbrellas. We saw a lot of people who had gone to Costco or Walmart and gotten chairs and groceries. A good option if you are there for a more than a few days. The shops and restaurants at the Hilton are all typical resort type. We only ate in one restaurant, Tropics. It was fine, but overpriced for the quality. Not unexpected, but we were tired and didn't want to venture out. The number one suggestion I have is to get out of the Waikiki area and travel around the island. A drive around Diamondhead and up to the Northshore will let you see how beautiful the island is. Go to Chinatown and have some great, inexpensive food. One of our favorite experiences was "The Hole in the Wall" tour. A great tour of the food of Honolulu. Read reviews and go...you won't be disappointed! I also want to mention the fireworks every Friday by Hilton. This was an unexpected surprise. We watched from our balcony and they were really great! We were told it is done every Friday unless the weather prohits it. We loved our time in Oahu and can't wait to return!

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: These condominiums are high end. I have traveled around the world and thes were definitely great accomodations. We had a 2 bedroom condo. It was not the biggest condo we ever had but it was spacious enough for my 2 nine year old boys to sleep on the pulluout couch and my daughter and mother to take the 2 full beds in one bedroom and my wife to take the king in the tohter room. The attention to detail that was mostly consisten in this tower was pretty impressive. It generally used quality materials and wen beyond mere trim to make more of a statement. The one exception I noticed was the base trim in our condo looked to be plastic because the paint was pealing in off in two different rooms. Overall this was a great vacation. The first day I went to costco to stock up. Costco is about 3 miles away. The second day I went to the Safeway to get the rest of the food. We went to Roys which was authentic Hawaiian cuisine it was ok then we walked down the strip. Second day did Duke's which was ok food. I would highly recommend that to fully experience Oahu you need to go native. Go see Lahai beach and Waimalea great boogie boarding and in car both are less than a 45 minute trip. Pack a picnic lunch. Only draw back to the condo was its location. It was at the west end of the Waikiki so it was not close to a lot of the action and the waves were pretty tame. By the way the room also had a PS3 in the room so the kids had a lot of fun.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: The Hotel is huge. Has four towers (Tapa, Kailua, Lagoon and Waikikian). We stayed at the Grand Waikikian. FOA are very professional and friendly. Concierge are very informative and helpful. The security is very punctual (we asked for help regdg in room safety dep box) and they come soon as they can. Maintenance...? It took the Grand Waikikian Hilton hotel to send a maintenance staff to our room TWO days! Imagine..travelling with fussy kids who wanted to watch tv or play video games with a malfunction tv? I keep calling for maintenance and they keep telling us back that they have no maintenance available? It was a shocking experience for me with a prestigous hotel like HILTON that's big...should have at least hire more personnel in their maintenance dept to address the needs of their guests. Aside from that..everything else is good. Very clean room, free internet, washer and dryer in your room, complete kitchen with dish washer, swimming pools, beaches are all well kept and the landscape are outstanding. The supply (shampoo, laundry soap, dish washer soap, etc) were always available at request. Check-in/out was fast. Bell man very very helpful. Overall it was great. The people at the lounge were very nice and helpful. They serve snacks at the lounge, a shower and a locker....A+

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: Travelling with the family, this accomodation couldn't be more convenient and cost effective. Attached to the Hilton complex it makes everything accessible - beach, retail, food, shopping and downtown Waikiki within walking distance. My husband and I had been to HHV seven years ago and loved it, this time back with our teenage girls we wanted to have the convenience of more space, a washer dryer and kitchen to make meals. The 2 bd, 2 bth was large, modern, clean and great to run back up from the beach to make a meal. Ala Moana shopping center was close by for groceries - it was great not to have to pay $$$ for each meal, we could cook and eat whatever we wanted. This complex does everything right, I couldn't think of anything else they could possibly do or provide for their guests....even down the the very modern departure/arrival lounge with showers, drinks food...it was fantastic to have access to while we waited to leave for the airport. Love this place, we will be back.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: We traded our Disney Boardwalk timeshare for a week at the GW. After spending the previous week in a small cabin cruising around the islands, the idea of the space in a 1 BR was most welcomed. We took Roberts from the pier and the large bus cannot drop you off at the GW. They drop you off at the Tapa bus depot and you have to schlep over to the GW but they will store your luggage for you there and deliver it to your room later. (The Tapa bus depot is also where you will pick up any tours you take.)Arrival: After arriving at about 10:30 we spent the day exploring the grounds since room-ready is not until 4:00. As others have said, the place is huge. It was a bit overwhelming that first day, but by day three we knew our way around, were taking shortcuts and it wasn't that bad. We ate lunch at CJ's and while it was very good, it came to $49 for two sandwiches with a ton of fries each, a soda and a beer, not exactly worth 50 bucks. Walked over to Hale Koa next door to pick up tickets and saw hamburgers for $4, cocktails for $7, etc., a much better value, although we never did eat there. Sat in the lobby for about an hour and they gave out fruit punch to people coming and going. (Saturday was the only day I saw this.) We got the room-ready call at 3:20, Room 1611. The elevators are now marked, so no problem getting to our room. The rooms: The hotel has 39 floors, and you need a key to access penthouse floors 35-39. From the outside you can see 5 balconies on Ala Moana Blvd,, 5 facing the ocean with little or no view because there is another tower right in front of them, and one balcony on each side of the building. Because ours was a trade-in, our room was city-view. Our balcony was on the left side of the building, about 25 feet long, with no balcony neighbors. The rooms were large, in perfect condition, and sparkling clean. The TV in the living room had a DVD player and game playing controls. In the lobby, there were free video rental kiosks, you just needed to get a card from the check-in counter. It was great to have a washer and dryer right in the room, not huge capacity but okay, and yes, the dryer did take forever, but when you turned it on it did say '1 hour 57 minutes, 2 hours 2 minutes, etc.' Trash and towel service was on Tuesday but for some reason we got extra towels on Sunday so we had plenty for the week with washing them. (Only use 2 teaspoons of laundry detergent in the washer.) They supply you with the detergent and when I needed more I just asked the housekeeper in the hall and was given extra with a smile. There is a guest services hotline and they were pleasant and accommodating both times we called with questions.  If you are a light sleeper and get city-view, you really want a room higher than floor 16. I was told the rooms were assigned on Thursday for Saturday check-in. The hotel is on the main street, between two traffic lights. There is constant traffic noise, not really loud but definitely not silent, especially when the buses and trucks accelerate as the light turns green, although after a few days, we didn't notice it anymore.We did not go to the concierge within 24 hours of check-in because we didn't want to be bothered by the timeshare pitch so we didn't get the HGVC tote that people were carrying around (It looked like a reusable grocery bag, but thinner,), nor did we get our blue 'experience' card activated. On the card in the room it said "weeks from $10,000 to $278,700." WOW!Food/dining: We ate breakfast in the room every day as we are not big breakfast eaters. The only dinner we ate on site was the last night because it was raining, so we went to Benihana's. At 5:30 there was no wait. (We saw loads of people waiting outside all week.) It was $84 for 2 Surf and Turfs, and 1 soda, similar in pricing to Kobe Steak House next door where we also ate. I found a grocery store about two blocks away, Food Pantry. It was a decent size with six to eight aisles and had anything you would need from eggs to steak, a deli section a produce section, etc. Prices were Hawaii prices, the biggest shock being milk at $4.09 a QUART, but it was nice to be able to get anything you wanted. (You cross the street, keep the Coffee House on your left, go to the next block and cross the street, make a left and it is halway up the block. Cross at the crosswalks. Jaywalking is against the law and you can get a ticket for over $100.)On property: The pools with slides were always crowded, but the ones without were not. The sand on the beach was very coarse. Beach rentals at HHV were very high, $42 an hour for the pedal floats. We did not rent the chairs/umbrella so no idea of the current price.The Honolulu Cookie Co. on property had the most delicious cookies. I bought 7 boxes to bring home. Only 5 of them made it back. Le Sportsac had two exclusive Hawaiian prints on a large selection of bags so I bought some for gifts. There were lots of jewelry stores, none of which ever looked busy, and of course 'there was a Pick a Pearl Factory.'. Also, there were some nice clothing stores like Tori Richard and Blue Ginger but I couldn't see spending $189 on a long sundress, although it sure was beautiful.More my speed/price range was the ABC store right in the Rainbow Bazaar. It was always crowded, but it was a nice size, lots of cheap souvenirs, postcards, T-shirts, etc. If you take the garage elevator, there is also an ABC store outside to the right, smaller, but a lot less crowded. We went to both often. Also, Lappert's ice cream in the Rainbow Bazaar was great.The business center on property has a post office substation. We sent two prepaid boxes home. They only take cash or traveler's check, so be prepared. I heard someone say they needed to connect to the internet and print seven pages. She was told it's a 15 minute minimum at $.50 per minute and a dollar a page. (I believe the internet is free at the GW, but there are six other towers so maybe she was from a different one.) The concierge will print your boarding passes for free. They also had a photo center there w/one machine like at the drugstores. I had 13 pictures printed out and a CD ($8.50) made for $13.26. You could not pick it up until the next day, but everything came out fine.Off-site: The walk to the main part of downtown by the International Marketplace is about 15-20 minutes. We took the bus twice and walked twice. If you are 65+ or have a Medicare card, the bus is only $1.We ate dinners off-site because we felt the on-site reviews were mixed and prices were high for a mixed review - Dinners at Roy's, Duke's, Kobe, Magic Show w/buffet at Hale Koa. Lunches at Orchid's Sunday brunch, Lobster tails for $28 at Blue Water twice, sandwiches in the room a couples of times, and the Shorebird w/$3.50 Mai Tais.Departure: There is a hospitality lounge available to you on check-out day for freshening up. You call the day before and pick a time and they give you 20 minutes per person. Ours was a regular room in the Diamond Head Tower. Since we could never both take a shower and get ready in 40 minutes, we just used it to change into traveling clothes. It was a nice touch. Overall: We absolutely loved the GW and would definitely return! We found everyone we came in contact with at the hotel to be very helpful and pleasant. We particularly loved Randy at the Tapa bus depot. What a nice guy! Prices were high on property, but prices in Hawaii in general are high. We loved the newness of the rooms in the GW and all the amenities available on property. We had a fabulous time!

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: Great apartments with all the facilities you need. Currently staying 7 nights.Beware checkin time is 4pm - room not ready a moment before. Long wait when you arrive at 9am.Hotel very geared up for Japanese. A lot of staff around, mostly talking to each other and not overly friendly. But if you want spacious accommodation it's still a great choice.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: We just returned from a great week at the Grand Waikikian. This is HHV's newest tower (timeshare) and everything was in excellent condition. The good: The Hilton Hawaiian Village is huge and has everything you could possibly need/want right inside the resort complex. Pools, restaurants, bars, luau, shops, fitness center, spa, beach, gardens, etc. Our unit was beautifully appointed with a full kitchen, washer/dryer, two spacious marble bathrooms, flat screen TV's with DVD player, highspeed internet access, and they just installed Sony Playstations while we were there - with free games (one at a time). The staff was very professional and there was absolutely no pressure to attend a timeshare tour, thank goodness!The not so good: We had a 2BR unit on the 10th floor, overlooking Ala Moana Blvd, which is VERY noisy all day/evening, making the lanai almost useless to us. Since we didn't spend a whole lot of time in our unit, it wasn't that big a deal - and we are not owners, so we didn't expect a great view. Also, for us, the beds were not all that comfortable (the mattresses were very firm, we prefer Westin's "Heavenly Beds") and the A/C didn't cool the master bedroom as well as the rest of the unit. At the lowest setting (68F), the other rooms were downright chilly, but the master bedroom was still warm. It would've been nice to open the door to the lanai to let breezes blow in, but the street noise was simply too loud. These were all pretty minor issues compared to the positives.Note: If you are more accustomed to resorts with "super pools" be aware that the pools at HHV are on the small side. There is one children's pool with a couple of slides, and it was always jam-packed with families! Waikiki Beach is the main attraction - not the pools.If you're looking for something interesting to do for a couple of hours, I'd highly recommend the Honolulu Academy of Arts tour of Doris Duke's oceanfront estate (Shangri La) in the Kahala neighborhood. It is stunning!

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: Very comfortable and close to everything. Loved having a washer and dryer in the room along with a full kitchen. Would stay here again if the price is right.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: My husband, 14 month old daughter, MIL, FIL, and I stayed in a 2 BR Oceanview Suite from 1/29-2/4/11. We received a special rate for sitting through their vacation club sales pitch, but we felt it was well worth the deal we received - and we actually considered buying. Our room was on the 25th floor and our view was wonderful. Yes, there is the Lagoon Tower obstructing part of the view, but we could still see lots of ocean and watch the surfers every morning from either balcony. The only other island we have visited in Hawaii is Lanai. We've been there twice in the past couple of years and have stayed at both Four Seasons properties there, as well as in one of the Four Seasons villas. This, of course, was a different experience, but we knew that going in. Honolulu is a big city. There is traffic and noise and homeless people and high-rise buildings everywhere. Everyone needs to understand this before planning a vacation in Honolulu, but this has nothing to do with the Grand Waikikian. We found the property to be quiet. We never once heard our neighbors, and yet we knew they were there just from running into them in the hallway on occassion. Yes, they certainly accommodate Asian travelers, but I do believe Honolulu is closer to Tokyo than it is to Washington D.C., so why wouldn't they? It's not like we didn't feel just as welcome, and I really enjoy vacationing with people from all over the world. We found everyone to be very friendly - both the staff and the fellow vacationers. As others have said, the rooms are nice. The lobby is lovely. And, the grounds were prettier than I had expected. I have no complaints about the property, but again, I knew it was going to be big and not a quaint intimate resort when we made our travel plans. Oh, and it is a resort and it is in Hawaii, so drinks and food will be expensive - there's no getting around that. We enjoyed happy hour at Tropics twice and ate and drank there for less than we would at home, so it's not all too bad. We also thought the on-site pizza restaurant was pretty good one night when we didn't feel like going out, and again no more expensive than in Chicago.We went to Pearl Harbor, which we were all very glad we did. We also headed to the North Shore one day, stopping at Dole Plantation on the way. It was a nice place to stop and stretch our legs. We ate at Giovanni's shrimp truck in Haliewa, which was delicious as well as a fun experience. We followed the coast around the island and stopped to play on the beach in Kailua late in the afternoon. That is a beautiful beach with warm water and powder white sand. It was a great beach for my young daughter to get in the water and play in the sand.I think the Grand Waikikian is a great place to stay for a family. We all had fun and enjoyed the property, from my 1 year old daughter to my 67 year old mother and father in laws. I don't quite understand all of the complaints, and I would certainly consider my husband and myself to be pretty picky travelers when it comes to our accommodations.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: My wife and two friends stayed at this beautiful condo/timeshare on the Hilton Hawaiian Village grounds and I must say it is the BEST OF BOTH WORLDS! We had all the amenities of the Hawaiian Village Hotel without the crowds and the limitations of a hotel room. Very convenient to the beach, Fort DeRussy, and shopping. A great stay. I will say that one of the front desk ladies could use some aloha spirit but everyone else went out of their way for us. Look for deals here...it will be worth your time!!

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: now this review is by a HGVC member. If you are a member and you stay here, you get more perks. member advantages: free to use fitness center. otherwise I want to say $12 or $20 a day. I forget which. Use of hospitality lounge on the 8th floor. They have tv, refreshments, pastries, showers, lockers and toiletries so you can use them prior to check in or after check out. you get nicknacks like eco bags and scratch off gifts. Also, they have their own activities like hula lessons and lei making. Lei making at the resort is $10 a person. here it is free! Also, you get a preferred shopper's card that gives you free cookies at honolulu cookie company, discounts at restaurants on site, etc. location: closest to the parking garage, there is actually a garage elevator or you can walk so it is very convenient if you have a car. All other buildings including the regular hotel rooms will require a walk.GW is off of Ala Moana Blvd so if you have a room on the lower level, you can hear street noise. We had partial ocean as well as street view but while we were there, there was a parade so it was great! Also, if you walk the blvd side, it is a short walk to the Kalia tower where the fitness center is located.Close to the new paradise pool with slides. Kids have to be 5 yrs old for the bigger slides but the smaller one can be used as long as they are 3ft tall and they were a flotation device. Wings or vestSuites/lobby: very beautiful with dark wood decor. you can tell the difference if you've stayed at the other towers or hotel portion. Full kitchen with ss and high end appliances. Again, you'll see the difference if you stay at the lagoon tower. The suites are smaller than the lagoon tower, but it has hardwood flrs throughout, stand alone shower and separate soaking tub. Washer/Dryer is in suite for free.I honestly don't know why some people are leaving bad reviews. Maybe it has to do with time of vacation? ppl compained about long lines at the slides, there were none. Lack of service, okay if you went while they are on strike, that's another issue. These are condo type suites so you can't expect daily maid service like the hotel rooms, etc.We might just be easy to please, but we had a great time!

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: While the property is marketed as a hotel, it is a time share facility with limited services (we were told that roll-away beds are not permitted in the units as a result for reasons that were unclear, and we requested that the sofa bed be made up for our children as we headed to dinner, and were told there would be a charge for the service). Housekeeping service was skipped on one day of our stay until we called to request it when it was clear that it wasn't happening; instead of an apology, the management insisted that we must have had our "privacy" card on the door (which was impossible since it was broken and couldn't have been hung on the door if we had wanted to). There are a number of concierge personnel, but each one we spoke with knew less than the one before regarding local sightseeing and dining options. Note that the location of the property is at the far western end of Waikiki, a fifteen minute walk from most of the shopping and dining. Also note that the Hilton Hawaiian Village can be a frenetic and claustrophobic place, so it is far from a relaxing getaway. The too-small fitness center is located in a different building in the complex, and getting there is an ordeal. While the rooms are fine, all else about the Grand Waikikian fails and it should be avoided in favor of the much better (and better located) full service hotels in the heart of Waikiki.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: Our extended family has vactioned several times at the HHV during the Christmas holidays. We have always stayed at the Ali'i Tower in the past. due to the special amenities that were once offered. Unfortunately, the Ali'i Tower's service and very wonderful staff have been replaced. As an example, continental breakfast is no longer offered on the pool deck floor by such wonderful staff as Mei-Ling, the evening pupus are no more (this was a wonderful time at the end of the day to chat with other guests). In summary the Ali'i Tower seemed to lose its charm. However, our extended family thought we would visit this one last time.....with some trepidation because of reported bed bug incidents and the mishandling (see TA reviews) of the guests' concerns. As a result, I began checking other hotels and rates that might accomodate us for our stay. THe Hilton Grand Waikikian seemed to be running a "sell-off: rate of POV 2 bedroom at $474 or an OV at $554 per night. ( Please do not quote me exactly on these figures....) But obviously, these were discounted rates perhaps due to low hotel occupancy. We booked a 2-bedroom and my parents reserved a 1- bedroom. Aurevoir Ali'I! Bonjour GW.Our stay was booked from Dec. 18-26....here are my thoughts!ARRIVAL:The GW has a lovely portico lobby for the arrival and departure of its guests. We were greeted by smiling bellmen, who were only too happy to assist us. The lobby was inviting with festive trees welcoming us to our Christmas Holiday! We walked over to the Hilton HHonors guest line and were quickly checked in by a very gracious and efficient front desk staff (I wish I could remember her name.) Not even 10 minutes later, we were in our OV room (2907...I think). THe 07 suite had an extended balcony that some of the other suites did not possess. We had requested 2 beds in the second bedroom to accomodate our 2 children. Our intial impression of the suite was that it was meticulously clean, well laid out, and deluxe (not over the top luxurious as the flooring was a look-a-like wood (vinyl) and not real hardwood. However, I was happy with our choice over the Ali'i Tower, as we now had a kitchen in addition to the 2 bedrooms. (Please don't misunderstand...I did not make dinner even once, but we had lovely breakfasts every morning on our lanai. The kitchen did its job, by providing an area to store snacks and breakfast offerings. With 2 growing teenagers, it was certainly nice to have some healthy food on hand. :) SUITES:As mentioned, previously, everything was clean and well appointed. The stacking washer/dryer came in handy for rinsing out swimsuits, etc. (I did not experience any difficulty with the dryer as other posters have noted.) Kitcehn came equipped with all the necessities including a blender for those frou-frou drinks enjoyed on the lanai and a steamer that would assist in Asian meal preparation. The living room area was on the small side but certainl.y very functional. There were 3 flat screen TV's in all.....so no fighting for a TV......we hardly even used 1 TV! The Master bedroom had an open concept bathroom with a soaking tub and a separate shower and 2 sinks. Thirsty clean towels were abundant. There was also a slider glass door that opened onto the extended lanai. (It did not seem that all suites had this large of a balcony...)The second bedroom just had a window (good if you have small children). This bedroom also had its own bathroom accessible by the bedroom or off the main living area. Clean, well appointed bathroom with one shower and 2 sinks (no Tub). All in all, a very functional and cute set-up for our 8 night stay.RESORT GROUNDS:Okay, so we have "been there done that" on many previous occasions. However, we had not tried the new pool by the GW and Lagoon Tower. Much smaller (and warmer) than the SUperPool, but obviously a pool geared to families with younger children. No worries, we used the loungers that faced the lagoon for relaxation while our kids enjoyed the Lagoon toys. The HHV does have beautiful albeit somewhat urban grounds. Compared to other hotels in Waikiki, this is positively an oasis. RESTAURANTS:DO NOT EAT AT THE HHV! I REPEAT...DO NOT EAT AT THE HHV (EXCEPT FOR Lapperts) Whoah, every year we expect the restaurants to improve, and every year we are again disappointed.BALI : Run away. WE reserved the Christmas Eve Dinner @ 75.00 pp. A set menu that looked interesting. On the restaurants defense, we requested and were given a wonderful sea side table.....and the salads were excellant....but sadly, this is where it declined. The lobster bisque..OKAY.And then the entrees There were 3 or 4 choices. Vegetarian, risotto, steak, chcken and a fish. The chicken entree was served on a tomato risotto. (think brined chicken with loose hanging skin appendages "on top" of a tomato soup infused cold risotto. Think again, Bali, my Mother, daughter and I were disgusted with this offering. My Father and son had ordered the steak....definitely more palatable but certainly nothing exciting....served warm, not Hot! My husband had the fish.Overdone and lukewarm. WOW.. not good, not good at all. Dessert was again Okay. In summary, our servers did their best, comped 3 glasses of wine (big deal). and P.S. we did not eat our chicken...we were asked if we wanted one of the other "PRE-MADE" entrees. We declined and went to Lapperts for some ice cream and coffee. Dear Readers, save your money....AVOID. ( Incidently, 2 years previous at Christmas Eve we had reserved the Christmas EVe buffet at the Rainbow with extended family and friends (this was done prior to departure 3 weeks in advance.) We were not given any notice that this buffet was cancelled at any time. However, upon confirming this reservation 2 days prior to our dining time, the restaurant let me know that they were not offering the buffet, Whoah, again, really Hilton!! We ate at their now defunct steakhouse which was the only place that could accomodate us at short notice. This was worse than horrible...I believe it is now closed. :)Tropics. Actually did not eat here. We tried but we were very off-put by the attitude of the hostess. We were looking for a table for 3 just have the lunch crowd rush. We were happy to sit anywhere. Lots of clean, available tables......But impolitely given a pager and told "we will call you!" Really, really. This is not a Michelin star restaurant and certainly not the only place on Waikiki beach. Check the attitude ( for the record, we were very polite). No thank, you. HHV ..fool me once (think Bali).........WE declined their silly wait time and then suddenly as we were departing....."Wait, I think we have a table!" . No way.......Well, Dear REaders, if you are still with me, I can recommend some excellant restaurant choices. Check out Sorrentos on top of the Ilikai, (THis restaurnat shares the same owners as Sorrento'ss on the Beach and Nic's Fish Market in Maui...amazing restaurants, incidently) for an amazing view, wonderful wait staff, incredible food and still less $ than Bali. I wish we would have discovered it sooner. Absolutely fantastic.Also, check out Roy's. Excellant fish. Surroundings not anything to write home about. Great waiters and service.For casual eats; Keo's ..good thai food at Ok prices, gaudy decor, slow service.Bubba' Gumps....you know what you get.....great shrimp, fast service.California Pizza Kitchen.....again great food, busy atmosphere.CONCLUSION:Our family is very well travelled. We enjoy luxe vacations. WE are not particulary enamoured of Waikiki having visited the other islands many other times. However, that was the locale for a family and friend celebration. IF I WERE TO RETURN TO WAIKIKI,I would not hesitate to stay at the GW if I came with my children. The staff (doormen, front desk, maids) were all very friendly and helpful. The building itself had a beautiful foyer and corridors. And yes, there were a lot of Asians....but who cares. They were very well mannered and visiting with their families just as we were. I never once felt that we were being overlooked in service because we were Norh American. Yes, it was busy....but we recongize that prior to travel.We had a memorable vacation with the exception of the HHV dining experiences. I am giving the GW an "Excellant" TA review, because for what we were expecting, this property delivered. But, just to be aware, it is not a "pampering, luxiourious kind of resort." For this reason, I will give it the "5 dots" because I received what I was expecting. At the end of the day, whether I stay at a 3 star or a 5 star property, I just want to achieve what I would expect for that type of establishment. Again, just my $.02. Happy and safe travels, everyone.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: Upon arriving at the hotel we waited for front desk staff who barely spoke and literally looked at us like we had just run over their dog. We were dressed well and arrived on time with patient children and very few bags- not quite sure what the problem was. I did however learn the meaning of 'mahalo'- Staff can be rude to you if they end every sentence with 'Mahalo'. They can also shoot dirty looks at you when you ask why your ocean view room in the lagoon tower has been moved to a tower off of the beach as long as they follow it with a 'mahalo'. It seems that booking through travel sites means the Grand Waikikian will try very hard not to honor your booking. We were finally moved to a better suite although not in the original tower which helped but did not live up to the expectations or the cost of 'beach views from all sides and being directly on the beach. We arrived to a room which despite the luxurious decor was filthy. The walls had black marks all over them as if it had just been used as a storage room for rubber tires, the artwork had spray marks from someones party all over it and the floors had clearly not been washed.we stayed there for 10 days and this did not change before we left. To be fair (and VERY THANKFUL) the bellman were incredibly friendly and always had a smile. As for the hotel encouraging you to spend your first few minutes with the concierge don't bother. It is a time share push and they bait you with a hotel discount card that surprise, surprise was not accepted anywhere we went! Yippee! From what I can tell the hotel believes the amenities were so great, service was notrequired. They were wrong. For our first trip to Hawaii we were excited for the welcoming 'Aloha Spirit '. For our first stay we were excited for the luxury and service. To our credit we didn't let them get us down and they will NEVER get us back. AT $950 a night I am sure we can find accomodations closer to the heart of the city with better access to the beach and better room service! ( the Hilton had cut off room service access for the businesses within it's own 'Hilton Village'!

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: Great rooms and location. Plenty to see in and around the Hilton Hawaiian Village.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: This hotel is very beautiful and new. They definitely cater to oriental visitors. Although the rooms are very clean and well stocked, this hotel is not worth the money. We did the Vacation Club sales discount and obligatory tour and sales pitch. We went to their sales "mill" on the high floor where the views were great. Our "partial ocean view" was only a slight sliver of ocean seen only when you stand on the edge of the balcony and lean across the rail. We complained and I got my money refunded for that upgrade, but not after talking to about 5 layers of management. Waikiki is congested, bloated, unfriendly, and dirty with many homeless people. We will never stay there again. Forget this place and go stay at the Villas at Turtle Bay Resort through vrbo.com

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: llocal no. 5 was on strike. will never stay in a hilton hotel again. hotel staff did nothing to help the guests. there was no house keeping,strikers would wake everyone up at 4:00am. I feel as though I was ripped off by hilton. thay just did not care.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: Huge beyond words! After finding the right entrance, we stood in the registration line for ever, waiting for the one and only receptionist to help everyone, and then there was a "gold line" (or called something like that) for VIP members or who knows what, and that line was constantly being taken first, for the most ridiculous questions. Pointed and headed up to our room, we found the room to be clean spacious and fitting the bill for our short stay. Our daughter was planning on sleeping on the sleeper sofa, and knowing this I always check for extra sheets, blankets and pillows before we settle in. We opened the sofa, only to find broken boards and a ripped mattress. Called housekeeping, no rooms that night, (expected that answer!) so we dealt with it for the first night, then we were moved to another similar room type 2nd night. All good with room remaining nights. No restaurant, no bar and no great lobby at this hotel View: Horrible view if you are stuck with a room on either "side " of the hotel, vs straight oceanfront. We overlooked a huge roof, ugly and unappealing, our first room was on the 3rd floor and overlooked the street and a very busy intersection. Expect to do a lot of walking, no matter what you are looking for. Pools, restaurants, bars, main street, beach, very far walk. As with other reviewers, outrageously priced drinks and food, is it not necessary to charge that much, for unfriendly uncaring service. There are so many other hotels in the area... go elsewhere

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: We stayed for a week in a 2-bedroom, 2-bath, full-kitchen, ocean view suite at the Grand Waikikian and had a blast! The Grand Waikikian is one of the towers of the Hilton Hawaiian Village so although you have a separate building, registration, pools, shopping etc, you also get to enjoy the beaches, pools, restaurants, shopping etc of the Village. The staff everywhere was incredibly friendly and helpful. The grounds are beautiful and filled with flamingos, turtles, parrots, penguins etc. Since we were there in September, there were no crowds and we were able to be seated immediately in the restaurants (although we did cook a few times while we were there)...and we were able to get activities scheduled around our schedule and not what they had available. The team running the surf/stand-up paddle board desk were amazing; Errol and his instructors - Chuck, Shane, Uncle D were awesome. My daughter learned to surf and the rest of us learned to paddle board. The resort is about 30 minutes form the airport and within walking distance of a downtown area with great restaurants and shopping. We'd return tomorrow and recommend to all our family and friends.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: Large 2 bedroom penthouse. Each room had a big deep soak jetted tub and large balconies with amazing views. The kitchen was fully stocked with appliances and dishes to cook your own meals. Very large and comfortable living and dining room.My family and I love staying at the Hilton Grand Waikikian. It is always a very fun and relaxing time staying there. There is always lots to do near by.I cannot wait to plan my next trip there again soon.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: We have been owners of HGVC since 2006 on the Strip in Las Vegas. We were offered the opportunity to visit the new tower of the Hilton Hawaiian Village, the Grand Waikikian. SInce we had two major life celebrations, husband's birthday and 30th wedding anniversary we chose to visit the third week of September 2010. We received access to a Ford Escape which was a wonderful car through Dollar rent a car and arrived at the Hotel from a 6 hour flight from LA tired but hopeful. We were placed in a room on the 5th floor facing the street and were advised that no other rooms were available. It was a one bedroom, slightly smaller than the Vegas Strip property, and frankly not as well appointed. Minimal use of granite and stainless, functional and clean, with heavy pieces of "Hawaiian" style wooden furniture. The tub while deep was NOT a jacuzzi tub. We learned later during our sales presentation that the only jacuzzi tubs were in the penthouse properties on the 34th plus floors. Our 'view' was of the main street with of course the constant din of city traffic. We're pretty easy going folks so we were comfortable, although if you're going to try and impress an Owner to purchase more points or a piece of a property, not a good location. As they say in real estate, Location, Location, Location! We have to commend the young woman RACHEL who was our assigned personal conciege during our visit. She took the time to call us before our trip, ask about our interests and if we were celebrating any events (a birthday and anniversary) and frankly was so personally CHARMING that we ended up 'hugging' friends by the end of our stay. Hilton needs more people like RACHEL working on the public facing end. She rescheduled our sales presentation to accommodate our schedules and even tried to locate tours we expressed an interest in. Speaking of the sales presentation, we met with our sales rep at the appointed time AND WE WERE KEPT COOLING OUR HEELS almost 20 minutes in the Sales Office Lobby until we were met by TERRY, who was COMPLETELY UNPREPARED FOR OUR VISIT. He knew nothing about us, hadn't done his research and began the presentation asking us, "DO YOU HAVE ANY QUESTIONS?". We asked a few questions and for a tour of the upper floors which we were graciously shown. Certainly spectacular views up there on the 37th floor, but for the $300,000 to purchase enough points to stay there for a week I didn't see the value. Unfortunately for Terry both my self and my husband have been in customer oriented industries for over 30 years. My husband in particular has been in real estate finance since the mid 80's. WE NEVER MEET WITH CLIENTS WITHOUT FIRST KNOWING WHO WE ARE MEETING, AND HAVING A GOAL AND OBJECTIVE FOR THE MEETING. Perhaps it was because the meeting was a reschedule, but as TERRY shuffled through our papers with Hilton we were struck by the fact that this sale WAS NOT going to happen. Once TERRY realized that we were NOT buying any more points (by the way $28,000 for 5K more AT that property, which by the way WAS NOT available), we were summarily, but courteously SHOWN THE DOOR. Fine with us, but startling none the less. Be advised that if you're given the $100 Hilton Dollars to use on property you'll be given conflicting information based upon where you try to cash them in. One restaurant on property REFUSED to take them for alcohol, fifteen feet away a second property restaurant took them for drinks WITHOUT QUESTION. Finally, be advised that Valet parking WHICH YOU CAN'T USE YOUR HILTON DOLLARS FOR is $30 a day. Self parkting is $26. And, you'll wait upwards of 15 minutes for your car when you call for it. By the way, lest you think that it's bold to complain about a sales package, we paid $899 for a 4 night stay, because we upgraded to the Waikikian. While this included a car, we will probably explore some other hotels and stays in the future.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: We took our family (one son and his wife and teenage son) to visit our daughter who is in the military and stationed on Hawaii. I was willing to spend the extra money to stay at a really nice resort. We rented a 2-bedroom, 2-bath suite with a full ocean view for $689 per night plus taxes. When we checked in the front desk lady was very nice but warned us about the housekeeping. She said if we put our "Do Not Disturb" sign on or if for any reason we sent the house cleaning away, they would not come back. So, we were very careful about making sure we didn't do this.... When we got to our room it was very nice but the first thing I noticed was that our "Ocean Front" room was blocked by the other buildings on the Hawaiian Village property in front of us... So, if you want an unobstructed ocean front view, DON'T stay at this property! Other disappointments:1. The house keeping NEVER came to our room... Not once and we called, went by the front desk and asked and nothing... 2. Our teenage son had to sleep on the pullout sofa which would have been fine if the sheets actually fit the bed! And, because we couldn't get service, he just wrapped himself in the blanket for the 2 nights and went without sheets....3. We had been very excited about the lagoon and it was actually one of the main reasons I booked this property... It was actually very disappointing. The water was murky all along the shore (almost like a film of whitish sunscreen) which kept all of us from going in the water. 4. This tower sits next to the pool area that has the slides for the kids, followed by the lagoon area. There are NO food or drink services by either of these areas! I had imagined parking myself on the beach of the lagoon, having a leisurely day with a drink in hand only to find out that if I wanted anything at all to drink or eat, I had to go to the ONLY outside bar on the property which was all the way on the other side of the resort by the other pool area! What a pain!!! This is a huge resort so be prepared to walk because nothing is convenient! 5. The second day we parked ourselves by the other pool so we could enjoy food and drinks.... There was ONE server for the entire area and she was slammed!! By the time our drinks got to us, they were watered down and nasty. Oh, and the minimal amount of food they offer is pretty pathetic for a "luxury" resort. SUPER expensive too. We got 3 hotdogs and a pizza type thing (no french fries... they don't have french fries!!) and the bill was almost $60!!All in all, VERY disappointing and I will never stay there again.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: We stayed here two nights prior to a cruise and two nights after. Our family of four stayed in a two bedroom unit. We loved the unit but had difficulties with the washer/dryer within the room. I chose this hotel partially because we needed to do laundry, as it was not our last stop before home. It was my first time staying in a HGV property and assumed it would operate like a hotel but I found guest services and the front desk to be indifferent. I would also avoid checking in on a Saturday as that is the day that most property owners arrive and depart, and reception was a zoo. I was also surprised that we were unable to find a restaurant still serving food after 10:00, considering that the resort is so large.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: We chose this hotel because it had the waterslide pool and the amenities of a condo (separate bedroom so our 6/8 year old boys could go to bed before us). It worked for us for those reasons, but there were times we wished we were closer to the center of Waikiki. Twice, we rented an umbrella down the beach for 1/2 the price of the hotel and had a better time in playing in the waves there. But our boys hated the whole walk back to HHV with sand-filled swim trunks. Probably would have chosen the Royal Hawaiian if I did it again, connecting rooms would have been perfect, but a lot more expensive than HHV Grand Waikikian.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: We stayed at this hotel for our Honeymoon. The day we arrived we were in a rush to get to our wedding reception, so we threw everything in the room, changed and left. We got bakc to the room later that night and notice that an envelope that was given for our wedding was missing. We went to bed and decided to search for it the next morning. We search the whole room and didn’t find it. We decided to ask the front desk if a maid had gone in around the time we had left that night, the workers said nothing and end up sending a security guard to talk to us. The security guard made us fill out a property lost form. After filling one out i ask, so did someone go in the room? Is that why i am filling this out? The security guard then told me that, that was info that he could not release. The hotel then made me wait hour half till a manager came down only to tell me that she could call HPD. WTF? Steal my [---], send me a security guard, make me wait hour half and then call the cops. Clean rooms, nice valet service if you want to pay $30/day, great location, but not worth the robbery!!!! They pretty much told me “too bad.” Well, too bad for them I posting this!!! DON’T GO TO THE GRAND WAIKIKIAN!!!

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: We are a family of 5 that stayed in a 1 bedroom suite. Got to say that the room was great. Hardwood floors, kitchen, washer/dryer, nice layout, top end furnishings. No complaints about the hotel - first rate!Now, about the HHV. We had just come from uncrowded Maui to very crowded Waikiki. My kids didn't even use the pool area because it was so crowded. 20 kids in line for the water slide...just packed. Also the lagoon didn't smell that great. Bottom line: Pros: Really nice rooms, decent service, great for famiies who like to cook breakast, etc. Cons: Too crowded and not relaxing....but if you don't care about crowds and lines, you'll enjoy yourself.
user_name:
newyorker88
New York City, New York

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: It was better than being at home with all the luxuries they have to offer! There was a lot of walking to do in the HHV but it's good exercise. I believe you must be a timeshare owner to stay here. Highly recommended. We stayed for 2 weeks & would definitely come back!

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: We were on the back end of our trip to Hawaii after having previously stayed on the eastern part of Waikiki. At first glance the location of HHV seems to be great. The Waikikian is a beautiful hotel / time share. The rooms are tip top with all the amenities; full kitchen, washer dryer, flat screens, cable TV, working AC. We had a 1 bedroom which was a bit small for a family of 4, the lanai was a bit small also. Since we were "owners" we had no maid service and had to call for extra coffee and towels. No biggie, except when we did call no one ever showed up! We had to stop a maid in the hall and grab some new towels. Besides that the staff were attentive and friendly. In all the Waikikian was a nice hotel, but unfortunately it is part of the nightmare that is the HHV.This was my second and last stay at HHV (previously without children). I am a very seasoned traveler, so let me list my gripes:1. The pools - The kids wanted to swim in the pools. However, unless you were down by 6:30 am you were not going to get a chair to be able to watch over your kids (especially at the one with waterslides). At one point it rained, people left there sandals on the chairs and went indoors to "reserve" their seats. This is BS. We swam in all the HHV pools except the private pool at Ali'i Tower. Every pool was grotesquely dirty. I had the misfortune of wearing goggles while I swam and got a first hand view of the "debris" field in the water including band aides and various "other" things floating around the bottom.2. The hottubs - forget about it. You'll be should-to-shoulder with kids and adults, no one obeys the limits on people allowed in the tubs at one time.3. The "Lagoon" - man it looks like it would be a great place to swim with the kids. Water is calm and flat. It looks clean... It's FREEZING. I mean if you are that hot and you need to cool off, by all means jump in. You won't stay in long, neither will your teeth-chattering blue-lipped children. Wear a wet-suit. Also, the water gets deep pretty quickly toward the center, keep your new swimmers close. Also, the sand on this beach might as well be a sidewalk, it is that hard - ouch!4. The Beach at HHV - OK, so you would expect the beach to be crowded because of the nature of the HHV Resort concept and its location. If you rent a couple chairs and an umbrella you can carve out your own little private hovel. However, you'll pay dearly for that privilege. The beach itself is nice, the ocean in this area is rocky, so wear some water shoes if you have tender feet.5. The Hilton Hawaiian Village - This is one of the "features" of staying at HHV. You have your own little village of way overpriced restaurants and shops to peruse. It is easy to take the kids on a stroll and let them shop around. The good news is that CJ's Deli is actually pretty good authentic deli food, I'd go there again. The bad news is that everything else is very average and is not priced averagely. Further, if you like to walk, getting anywhere else outside of HHV is a pretty good hike!6. Tropics Restaurant - Here's the deal. It is a gorgeous looking place. Its right on the beach and has a terrific view of the ocean. You get there early and try to get a table and find out they are booked. So they'll give you a buzzer and "buzz" you when a table is ready. There are couches outside and some torches and a band playing Hawaiian tunes. Go get yourself a beer while you wait. However, don't get one for your wife they will only server you one drink at a time, she'll have to go get her own. OR you can wait for a waitress, but you'll be seated in the restaurant before she arrives. Once inside odds are against you to get a beach front table, since there are more inside tables than out. Still the inside is nice and a great looking place. Here's where things get bad. The food is just aweful. Maybe our expectations were too high? But for the fan-fair and 1.5 hr wait combined with tasteful design and beachside prices I expected more than Hilton Cafe Food. Regular travelers who stay at Hilton's, Marriotts, etc know what I 'm talking about here. Hotels usually have 1 or 2 "quality or named" restaurants and 1 cafe, (usually for bfast or cheap late meals). Cafe food is not what you would expect from Tropics, but its what you get and you pay top $ for this. This was by far the most disappointing part of our stay at HHV.In would recommend the Grand Waikikian as a hotel but not the HHV as a resort.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: We stayed in a two bedroom/two bath unit at the Grand Waikikian on the 24th floor. It was a beautiful unit, and completely met our needs for our 3 night stay. Our party consisted of myself, my husband, and my adult son. This hotel has only been open about one year, and everything is maintained beautifully.Pros: Leis upon arrival; great customer service at both front desk and concerige; beautiful view at 24th floor oceanview unit; HHV is an amazing facility complete with shops and restaurants; HHV is walking distance to most sights in Waikiki. Cons: Crowded!!!! We were there peak season (after xmas, but before Near Years) and everything was too busy. It felt like Las Vegas during high season to us (just warmer and on a beach). Pool chairs were all "taken" (aka: reserved) at pool opening. Beach towel area closes at 5pm, so if you come back after a long day of sightseeing, you won't be able to get a towel if it is after 5pm. Pool hours: they all close early (by 7pm). So, if you were looking at having a nice relaxing hot tub after dinner - won't happen. During our 3 day stay, we never once actually got in the pool. Tried a couple of times and gave up.Possibly we are unique travelers, but love going to out of the way places that are relaxing and peaceful. This certainly did not meet our needs in that manner. Will we come back? Possibly - for a very short stay and we would have to have a reason to venture to this beautiful, but very crowded resort.As far as the Grand Waikikian, it is amazing and if you like or are used to traveling (and don't mind) to very busy spots - this might be what the doctor ordered.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: The location was very nice, you could see the Pacific Ocean and Diamond Head. I suggest hiking Diamond Head, not too hard of a hike, it also had an excellent view at the top of the mountain. They also had good service and gave you leis as you entered the hotel. The Hilton Hotel Village was also filled with shops and many good restaurants. If you have children they would love it here, there is a salt-water lagoon right by the hotel; they also have a great pool. If you are coming to Waikiki for business, family time, or with your spouse I suggest staying at the Grand Waikikian.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: We spent a week at the Grand Waikikian, taking advantage of their special rates for people contemplating buying a time share. The new building is very nice, with posh public areas and comfortable suites (ours was a one-bedroom). The Hilton Hawaiian Village is beautifully maintained and decorated and it was grand being surrounded by so many happy families with young children enjoying all of the unexpected amenities, such as the penguins and the parrots. There is a large man-made lagoon and though the pools are small, they are beautifully landscaped. You can stock your refrigerator for breakfast and casual meals by taking a 15 minute walk to the supermarket in nearby Mauna Loa shopping center.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: ALOHA, the Grand Waikikian timeshare building has all first class decor, beautiful waterfalls on both sides of entrance driveway to open air front desk check-in and lovely gardens every where you look. There is alot of walking involved as their elevators are at far end of long hallway and the staircaseS to get into Hilton Hawaiian Vlg or to Paradaise Pool are back at check-in/driveway area. There are a few side door staircases that you can take down to driveway cut over to front check-in counter/shops of HHVlg. But, basically if you stay at HHV you best understand it's huge complex and there is no way around not hiking it every where, we enjoy the exercise though and the gardens are gorgeous all around grounds! The 2 bdrm/2bath premier ocnvw condo has elegant furniture and all hardwood flooring, with granite counter tops. The living room is tight, especially if you fold out the sofa sleeper, you basically have to climb over to get to kitchen area. Don't know if it's mostly timeshare situation vs hotel room, but the hardwood floors need good moping, turned our feet or stockings black with dirt and all the mirrors were so dirty had to really use elbow power to clean them to be able to see ourselves!!! One negative, in these very front of building units, while the view is as good as you will get toward Harbor and between Ali'i Twr & Rainbow Twr to left (as Lagoon Twr is in front of GW blocking majority of Lagoon and ocean view with Rainbow Twr blocking ocean views to left of Lagoon Twr ) there is NO sun on front balcony until after noon,. Although there is side balcony off second bedroom facing Tapa Twr with views of mountains to left (between Kalia & Tapa Twrs) and ocean between Ali'i and Rainbow Twr, BUT they did not put table and chairs or sunbather on that balcony, only one chair and small end table ??? rendering it very useless if you want to relax in sun in mornings! Cost cutter that is annoying and ridiculous after making sure to spend on interior amenities of condo. Another annoying timeshare factor, is upon check-in if you don't get agent in good mood or generous attitude, all your hard work to secure best possible unit/views, is immediately shot down if they deem you are not getting above 20th floor to see over the Ali'i Tower to ocean (you will only get view of ocean between Ali'i Twr and Rainbow Twr, I call that PARTIAL OCNVW, which only gets worse the lower your floor goes because of trees in village, along with parking lot roof next to GW! If there are upper floor units available for week's stay (which there were lots, we checked later at night at front desk), why not give them to customers and keep the good will/feelings going?$! Front desk agents on power trips ?!There is lots to do on Oahu, tons of excellent restaurants ie Duke's, Hula Grill, Ocean House, House Without A Key, Yard House, Ruth's Chris Steak House, Benihana's, etc and shopS. Have to rent car to get out to sightsee because there is so much to enjoy as far as beaches and natural Oahu beautiful sights.Next time if we rent or do timeshare here we will stay at Lagoon Tower, as they are refurbishing them now, views are much better and units have more space in living room area.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: While the hotel, room, view and location were all beautiful, we were very disappointed in the level of customer service we received. When booking the room we were told, don't book a rental car in advance, just see us the morning you want a vehicle and we'll arrange it for you. We went down the morning we wanted a vehicle, at 7:00 AM when the concierge opened and were informed "we don't do that" nor would they recommend somewhere. We asked for directions numerous times, as first time visitors, we were unaware that "local" directions are nothing like what they are in the other states, no North, South, East, West, only toward diamondhead, or away from the ocean, and that's only on one side of Oahu, locals on the other side have a different set. All that to say, you better have a good GPS if you plan on visiting more than just waikiki beach because you sure won't get a straight answer out of anyone who works at the GW.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: We stayed at the Grand Waikikian located in the Hilton Hawaiian Village after our NCL cruise. The Grand Waikikian is newest building in the Hilton Hawaiian Village and its units are all time share suites with kitchen and washer/dryer. The lobby is beautiful and the rooms are very nice. Make sure you ask for a oceanview on a higher floors and not a partial oceanview if you really want an ocean view. I personally don't think it is worth the extra money for a partial oceanview when you can only see a small view of the ocean between other buildings (we were already on the 22nd floor). Please understand that the guests at the Grand Waikikian share the grounds of the Hilton Hawaiian Village and that includes the pools and lagoon . This is a huge place with six high raise hotel buildings. I think the pool areas are too small for a hotel this size and it is way over capacity especially during weekends. Self parking is $24 a night in a indoor parking lot that's larger than some of the shopping mall's parking lot. The signage and instruction getting around the parking lot is terrible. I spend time looking for my car or getting out of the lot everyday because there were no clear directional signage. Maybe valet would have been a better choice. The staff's services are inconsistent. Many of them were not friendly thru out the village. They were not flexible and doesn't seem like they want to do any extra for the quests. For example, we wanted to get to the beach early and got to the pool side at 7:50 am for our towels. The staff at pool side told us we have to wait until 8:00 am or we have to walk to a different building for the towels. The other building requires about 10 minute walk. Since he was doing nothing and waiting for 8:00 am, what's wrong with handing out a towel to your guests 10 minutes earlier and make them happy? We stayed at Aston Waikiki Beach Hotel (3 star) for one night before our cruise and the staffs were much more friendlier and helpful. The Hilton Hawaiian Village provides many convenient for family with young children. It has many shops and restaurants within the village. However I find it too crowded and overwhelming at times. Also the staff did not impress me at all with the exception of the staff at the Italian restaurant. If you want to stay here make sure you stay at the Grand Waikikian building. Some of the other buildings and rooms in the HHV are really dated for a 4 star hotel and not worth the money.
user_name:
thc152
New York City, New York

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: My husband and I had a great stay at the Grand Waikikian August 28-September 4 for our 5 year anniversary trip to Hawaii. Check in was very quick and the person who helped us was extremely nice. I asked about the cost of upgrading to a ocean view room and their were none available, but when we arrived at our room it was a partial ocean view. It was mostly city view, but did have a partial ocean view if you looked to the left. We originally booked city view so I wasn't expecting any type of ocean view. I assume we were slightly upgraded, but didn't ask so can't be sure. Our room also did not have the tub in the room, just a regular bathroom, which was nice and spacious, but not the big tub, so not sure about that. As other reviewers have noted, the Grand Waikikian is quite a ways from the main strip, but we did not find this to be a problem for us. We walked down (~20 minutes) one night and took the bus on a another occasion, but honestly didn't have a reason to go there everyday. There are plenty of restaurants near the Hilton Vacation Village. On site restaurants are super expensive, so we mainly ate offsite, but honestly everything in Hawaii is expensive so if you're going, unless you plan to eat at McDonald's everyday, be prepared to pay for food. Although we didn't cook in the room, we did buy some things for breakfast which saved money on a few of our days there so the fridge did come in handy. The Ala Moana shopping center is within walking distance (or a short trolley ride) and has a Foodland grocery store there. Again, this is not the mainland so do not expect mainland prices, even at a grocery store.We rented a car for 1 day to drive up to the North Shore which was nice. I highly suggest doing that. We took other posters advice and parked at the Marina just past the Grand Waikikian entrance. BEWARE that the machines do not give you change. We thought it did and put in a $5, but only needed it for about 12 hours. Our ticket was stamped for 12 hours, but we didn't get anything back. Granted we only lost $2, but I just hate when something like that happens. Someone who was in front of us lost there money as well except it was because they took too long as they were looking for extra change. They didn't get a ticket at all and had to pay all over again. Overall though, there was plenty of space and our car was safe. Oh, we also rented from Alamo which was right across the street. There was also an Enterprise and National in the same center. I would personally say there is really no reason to rent a car for your entire stay. We took the city bus several time and it is cheap and easy. It is $2.25 per person and you can get a transfer that lasts for 4 or 5 hours, which means you do not have to pay again on your way back to the hotel. We did this to visit Pearl Harbor, Diamond Head, and just for Dinner. $4.50 roundtrip for 2 people can't be beat. The concierge at the Grand Waikikian was very helpful in helping us determine which bus we needed to catch and printing off schedules for us. Super easy!Overall, my husband and I thought the room was very nice and we spent a lot of there. The pool was crowed when we first arrived, but by Tuesday, the pools were much less. I think we went right after peak season though. Pools, beach, and rest of Hilton Village were just a short walk. I really like the location of Grand Waikikian as it was convenient to everything...restaurants, bus stops, shopping, beach. We really didn't have any complaints.Other tips: Visit the Swap Meet for all your souveniers. Everything there is much cheaper than the stores around the hotels. The only thing we didn't buy there was Hawaiian chocolate, which they probably couldn't sell out there due to the heat.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: We booked a 2 bedroom oceanview and were upgraded to a penthouse 2 bedroom on the 39th floor. The views were terrific. Access to the concierge lounge for continental breakfast and evening snacks was a bonus. The suite was wonderful. The housekeeping was excellent. The only issue with the suite was that the dryer takes all day to dry anything. The pool at the GW was mobbed with kids (including my own) using the water slides. It was not a relaxing environment at all. The Super pool was a little better. We did not care for the lagoon at HHV . The man made "beach" felt like hard concrete covered with a very thin layer of very rough sand. We also did not care for the stretch of Waikiki beach that fronts HHV. We found it murky and seaweedy. Overall, though, we enjoyed HHV, though it is a crowded mega resort. The grounds are lovely. Lapperts coffee and ice cream is not to be missed. The Friday night hula and fireworks show was fun too. We were glad we rented a car and explored Oahu. We loved he Kahala area, Diamond Head, the North Shore and the southeast coast.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: My family stayed at the Grand Waikikian for a week in July. We found the rooms to be very comfortable with a great balcony to enjoy the great ocean views. We sat on the balcony every morning and watched the dozens of surfers outside our window. The rooms were quiet. We did not hear any outside noise from the pools, etc. The beds were very comfortable, even the sofa bed which our 12 year old slept on. We have two children ages 10 an 12, and they enjoyed using the pools and the lagoon. It was great to have the shops and eateries right on site. It was also very convienent to pick up tours from within the Hilton Village. Overall it was an excellent week. We found everyone to be very friendly and eager to help! We would definitely return again and will recommend this hotel to friends traveling to Hawaii in the future!

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: My wife, two children (21&16) and I stayed at the Hilton Grand Waikikian from July 20th to July 26th. This is our third trip to this resort and we thoroughly enjoyed our previous stay at the Lagoon tower. We were looking forward to the new tower. Our family has been a HGVC owner for over ten years and we have truly enjoyed the HGVC ownership until our visit to the Hilton Grand Waikikian. Being a HGVC owner, we know the practice of room assignment and had requests notated for our reservation. None of the requests were met. The check in process seemed smooth but not friendly and the room was not the luxury we were expecting or lead to be expecting. We felt that we were bumped to a very low 11th floor. When we confronted the front desk, we were told that the building is fully booked and nothing could be done. In all my travels, I was surprised of the callous answer. In addition when you check in, make sure you request to have your room card specially coded to use the parking garage if you have a rental car otherwise you will have an angry line of cars behind you while you are trying to swipe your room key.To be fair, the room was very clean and well maintained; of course the place is new. All appliances work well and were clean. The rooms were comfortable and very clean. The lobby area is very nice and very well decorated. The resort has many amenities, shops and restaurants. The beach is nice and a protected area for swimming. It truly is a good family resort.Something has changed since our previous visits. The staff did not smile or acknowledge you but to be fair there were a couple of occasions of friendly staff members. As a return visitor we were expecting a level of service we have come to know from Hilton due to previous visits. Our room living area was very small, in fact smaller the any previous HGVC property we have visited in our travels.We tried to use the pool next to the GW. During busy period, too crowded and even counted fifteen small children in the Jacuzzi or hot tub (on several days). Also, people put towels on chairs (in the morning) to reserve a spot, even though they are not at the pool.We have visited other Hilton properties and after we left the GW, we stayed a week on the Big Island at a Hilton GVC resort. Level of service on the Big Island was excellent. Staff friendly and our suite was very nice in comparison to the GW.In summary, I would recommend a visit to the facility but would recommend the Lagoon Tower. If you had to stay in the Hotel the Rainbow tower has a great view and we also enjoyed our stay in the Tapa Tower (years ago), ocean facing corner room. To add, I was on vacation and I am not a confrontational person or one who complains or is demanding. I love HGVC, they have been great up to this point. It just seems that the staff is not happy working at this resort. I prefer to let my wallet finalize any negotiations.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: Our family of five stayed for five nights in a one bedroom unit. We chose the Grand Waikikian over the other Hilton Towers for the extra space and the in-room kitchen and laundry and to be in a location that was quieter. It was all of those. The rooms were comfortable and clean yet on the small side. The laundry was helpful, but took forever. It was near impossible to get a chair at the pool. The lagoon was close by, but the ocean beach...which was wide and open...was a little further away. This was fine for our family. As a Hilton Gold, we recieved complimentary breakfast in members lounge in the Rainbow Tower...coffee, juice, pastries, fruit and hard boiled eggs.Overall, this hotel worked for us. It was good, not very good.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: This is our second visit to Honolulu as HGVC timeshare owners. Our previous visit was spent at the Lagoon Tower, and on this visit we were in the new Grand Waikikian Tower at the Hilton Hawaiian Village.First, the new tower is quite lovely, with upscale decor and amenities throughout. Since everything is practically brand new it's hard to complain about the place.Our first three nights were in the Penthouse on the 37th floor. We had a two room master suite and there is no doubt this unit is very deluxe and upscale. Stainless steel, marble, granite and topnotch appliances, furnishings and bath amenities etc. We had a beautiful view of the ocean and the Hilton property.Out next seven nights were in a two bedroom plus unit on the 31st floor. We specifically asked to be on the Ewa/Harborside view since we wanted to see the fireworks on the 4th of July. So while we did miss the open ocean view from the Diamond Head side, we had a great view for the fireworks.These rooms are smaller and more "cozy" than the two bedroom penthouse. Instead of a separate dining room and table, there was a cute nook area, that we actually preferred over a separate dining area. There was not as much granite/marble and the appliances were black and not SS, and the soaps were standard fare rather than L'Occitane as they were in the penthouse. Here rather than a two king bedroom master we had a king bedroom and two queens in the second bedroom, which was better for our family of four.There is no doubt this is a very lovely project.We found the service to be excellent and we had no problem with the valets or bellhops, we simply called ahead and usually found our car waiting for us.Now for the negative - While this is a beautiful property, in my opinion it is no match for the older Lagoon Tower which is lagoon front and only steps from the beach. To us the Grand Waikikian was just too far removed from the overall Hilton Village and way too far from the beach. Now for some this wouldn't be a problem, but for us, we will book the Lagoon Tower if we do make it back to Honolulu, simply because we prefer its location over the Grand Waikikian.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: Condo-style hotel, rooms are nice but not extraordinary. Service was great but the staff seems small and it was often hard to find help. Our room had a "partial view" of the water which meant you can see the beach and water when you walked out on to the balcony and looked to your left. But the sights and sounds from our balcony were dominated by downtown Honolulu. On the other hand, we were only a 2-minute walk away from Waikiki beach!

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: I stayed with my family for one week at the Grand Waikikian. The timeshare was spacious and well appointed. The Hilton Hawaiian Village was beautiful but very crowded. The food in the restaurants was good but way overpriced. We ate many of our meals across the street at the 24 hour coffee house. The pools were also extremely busy and it was often difficult to get chairs unless you arrived very early/late in the day. The parking fee of $25 per day was way too much and parking was not convenient if you were staying in the Waikikian. Save your money and park in the public harbor parking lot just past he entranced to the Waikikian. The Hilton Hawaiian Village was pretty far from the heart of Waikiki beach and all it's shops and restaurants. If you have a car it's not a problem but parking was hard to come by. Overall our stay was pleasant but we were able to stay there at a discounted price. If I had to pay full price I would have stayed elsewhere.

hotel_name: Grand Waikikian by Hilton Grand Vacations
review_body: We stayed at the GW from June 2 thru June10. We have stayed at the Lagoon tower many times and were looking forward to experiencing the new tower. There were 6 of us, my husband and myself and our three grown kids(25,21,18) plus our other son(best friend) 18.We were booked in room 3005, a two bedroom plus. I remembered reading the new entrance was on the backside and not to go in the main HHV entrance so we had no trouble arriving. We were a day late due to airline and were allowed to check-in at 1:00 p.m. The staff was very friendly and helpful, the bellman brought our luggage up within 5 minutes of us reaching our room. The new lobby and furnishings are beautiful koa wood and traditional hawaiian. It is very elegant. The elevators are quite a distance from the lobby, you will walk a lot here as the new tower is far from the rest of the village. The rooms are very nice but smaller than the lagoon tower. They are new so are in good condition, but I prefer the spaciousness of the living/dining area in the lagoon tower rooms. The view is good but you can barely see Diamond Head from your lanai unlike the beachfront view in the lagoon tower. We had a king room and a 2 double bed room set-up. My one dislike for the six of us is yes there were two bathrooms but the shower in the master is glass and right in the bedroom. Therefore, no one can shower with someone else in the room. A separate shower/toilet combo would be good for having 6 adults in one unit. The washer and dryer are right in your room, they are apartment size and front loaders.
